questions.text:
A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of shortness of breath and swollen extremities for 2 weeks. He has had excessive night sweats and a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss over the last 8 weeks. He had an anterior myocardial infarction 3 years ago. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He immigrated from Indonesia 4 months ago. He works in a shipyard. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 48 years. Current medications include insulin, aspirin, simvastatin, metoprolol, and ramipril. He is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 46.7 kg (103 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/95 mm Hg. Examination shows generalized pitting edema. There is jugular venous distention, hepatomegaly, and a paradoxical increase in jugular venous pressure on inspiration. Chest x-ray shows bilateral pleural effusion, patchy infiltrates in the right middle lobe, and pericardial thickening and calcifications. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



 Urea nitrogen
25 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.5 mg/dL


Urine



 Blood
negative


 Glucose
negative


 Protein
1+


Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Uremia is the excess of urea nitrogen in the blood, typically caused by chronic kidney disease. Severe uremia may affect the heart, causing fibrinous pericarditis. This patient has pericarditis; however, this patient's urea nitrogen is only marginally elevated, making uremia as the explanation for this patient's symptoms unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Myocarditis is inflammation of the heart muscle most commonly caused by viruses. Acute viral myocarditis is typically a sequela of a viral upper respiratory infection and may lead to concurrent inflammation of the pericardium. Although this patient's shortness of breath and fever may point to myocarditis, this patient does not have any chest pain or cardiac arrhythmias, which are typical findings in myocarditis. Additionally, pericardial thickening and calcifications suggest chronic pericarditis.

C) INCORRECT:

Type 2 diabetes mellitus is a chronic disease affecting the metabolism of glucose. Complications of diabetes mellitus include diabetic nephropathy, which may present with peripheral and pulmonary edema in cases of nephrotic-range proteinuria. However, the laboratory values only suggest mild kidney damage, and diabetes mellitus would not explain the findings of jugular venous distention and the positive Kussmaul sign.

D) CORRECT:

Shortness of breath, night sweats, weight loss, low-grade fever, and patchy pulmonary infiltrations in a patient who has recently migrated from an endemic region strongly suggest tuberculosis (TB). TB can affect any organ, including the heart, and is the most common cause of constrictive pericarditis in countries with a high TB prevalence.

E) INCORRECT:

Amyloidosis is characterized by the build-up of abnormal protein fibers in various tissues. In the heart, amyloidosis causes restrictive cardiomyopathy, manifesting with signs of diastolic heart failure. Although the findings of dyspnea, jugular venous distention, and hepatomegaly may suggest heart failure, amyloidosis would not explain the low-grade fever, night sweats, and pericardial thickening seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Asbestosis is a chronic lung disease that results from exposure to asbestos fibers. Although this patient's occupation as a shipyard worker may suggest possible exposure to asbestos fibers, the absence of cough and interstitial fibrosis on imaging makes this diagnosis unlikely. Moreover, asbestosis does not cause constrictive pericarditis.

G) INCORRECT:

Postmyocardial infarction syndrome, also known as Dressler's syndrome, is an immune-mediated inflammation of the pericardium that usually occurs 1–8 weeks after myocardial infarction. Although this patient presents with pericarditis, the occurrence of it 3 years after this patient's myocardial infarction would be very unusual. While this diabetic patient may have recently experienced a second, asymptomatic (“silent”) myocardial infarction, pericardial calcifications and patchy pulmonary infiltrations make another underlying etiology more likely.
questions.hint: Generalized pitting edema, jugular venous distention, paradoxical increase in jugular venous pressure on inspiration (Kussmaul sign), and pericardial calcifications are all suggestive of constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the physician for a preplacement examination and tuberculosis test before volunteering at a public library. He has had a mild cough, sore throat, and occasional headaches for 1 week. He has hypertension and gastroesophageal reflux disease. He works as a mechanic and has never traveled outside of the US. He lives alone and has had no known contact with anyone infected with tuberculosis. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 27 years and does not drink alcohol. Current medications include ramipril and esomeprazole. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 81/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 145/75 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 6200/mm3 and a hemoglobin concentration of 13.8 g/dL. A rapid test for COVID-19 is negative. A tuberculin skin test results in an induration of 13 mm in diameter after 50 hours. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Repeat tuberculin skin test after 8–10 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A chest x-ray is used along with another screening test, tuberculin skin test (TST) or IFN-γ release assay, in the initial workup of latent TB infection in certain patients who have a high risk of false negative results on the latter test (individuals with HIV, children aged < 5 years, and/or immunocompromised patients). In all other patients, a chest x-ray is only performed if the skin test is positive in order to rule out active TB. This patient has a negative TST, so a chest x-ray is not indicated.

A chest x-ray may also be performed as part of the initial diagnostic workup in patients with respiratory symptoms (productive cough, dyspnea) and/or systemic symptoms in order to narrow down the differential diagnoses (e.g., active TB). This patient only has mild respiratory symptoms that do not warrant a chest x-ray at this point.

B) CORRECT:

In patients with no risk factors, a tuberculin skin test (TST) is positive if the induration is ≥ 15 mm. Negative TST indicates that the patient has not been infected with TB or has been infected recently, and not enough time has elapsed for the body to react to the skin test. This patient has no signs or symptoms that suggest active or latent infection, so no further management is indicated at this time. The threshold for a positive TST depends on the patient's individual risk factors. (See “Positive TST according to induration diameter” table.)

Note that routine screening for latent TB infection (LTBI) has been replaced by a targeted screening strategy that mainly includes patients at high risk of infection or disease progression. However, there are some exceptions, such as baseline TB assessment of health care workers and volunteers. LTBI testing is typically not recommended for individuals with low risk of exposure; exceptions include local regulations that mandate broader testing policies.

C) INCORRECT:

Interferon-γ release assay (IGRA), a screening test for TB infection, may be performed as an initial test or as a follow-up test (dual testing strategy) if the initial tuberculin skin test is negative but there is high clinical suspicion of tuberculosis infection (e.g., exposure to an individual with active pulmonary TB) or high risk for infection, disease progression, or a negative outcome of infection (e.g., immunocompromised patients). This patient has no risk factors for infection with or exposure to M. tuberculosis (e.g., travel to a high-prevalence country, residence in a high-risk setting), and shows no clinical features of TB (e.g., weight loss, chronic cough).

D) INCORRECT:

A repeat test is recommended as part of a postexposure workup for contacts of individuals with active pulmonary TB. Patients with a negative initial tuberculin skin test should be tested again 8–10 weeks after the last exposure (either with TST or interferon-γ release assay). This patient has no history indicating exposure to active TB.

E) INCORRECT:

Isoniazid and rifapentine for 3 months (3HP, short regimen) is one of the preferred treatment regimens for patients who have been diagnosed with latent TB infection (LTBI). A diagnosis of LTBI is confirmed if a patient's screening test is positive, but there is no clinical or radiographic evidence of active TB. This patient has a negative tuberculin skin test, so therapy is not indicated.
questions.hint: This patient has no risk factors for tuberculosis (TB) such as homelessness, close contact with a patient with active tuberculosis, or migration from a country with a high burden of TB.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to a refugee clinic by his parents. He has not seen a physician since leaving Ukraine with his family 2 months ago. His parents report that he has been healthy except for occasional episodes of nasal discharge and sneezing when playing outside. Medical history is remarkable for infantile atopic dermatitis treated with emollients. He received all appropriate childhood vaccinations in Ukraine, including the BCG vaccine, as Ukraine is considered a country with a high burden of tuberculosis. He has two healthy siblings. His mother is a physician and his father works in agriculture. Vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The tuberculin skin test (TST) is used to diagnose LTBI. However, because TST is associated with a high false positive rate in individuals with prior bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG) vaccination, a different test is more appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients are screened for LTBI based on their likelihood of having TB, risk of progression to active disease, and potential benefit from treatment. No further evaluation is appropriate for patients with a low probability of TB. This patient recently immigrated from a country with a high TB burden and has close contact with a healthcare professional. Therefore, screening for LTBI is indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

A chest x-ray is used along with another screening test in the initial workup of LTBI in certain patients who have a high risk of false negative results on the latter test (individuals with HIV, children aged < 5 years, and/or immunocompromised patients). In all other patients, the standard modality is typically sufficient for LTBI screening and may be followed by a chest x-ray if the initial test is positive in order to rule out active TB.

A chest x-ray may also be performed as part of the initial diagnostic workup in patients with respiratory symptoms (productive cough, dyspnea) and/or systemic symptoms in order to narrow down the differential diagnoses (e.g., active TB). This patient only has mild respiratory symptoms (most likely due to a seasonal allergy) that do not warrant a chest x-ray at this point.

D) INCORRECT:

Microscopic examination of the sputum with acid-fast stain may be part of the management of patients with suspected active TB. Culture of the sputum is the gold standard test to confirm active TB and test for drug susceptibility and typically takes 2–6 weeks to become positive because of the slow-growing nature of the disease. However, neither of the tests is part of the initial workup for LTBI.

E) CORRECT:

The interferon gamma release assay (IGRA) is a blood test used to diagnose exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis by measuring the level of interferon-γ expressed by T cells after coming into contact with the bacteria. This test uses M. tuberculosis-specific antigens and is therefore unaffected by prior bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG) vaccination or prior exposure to nontuberculous mycobacteria. Tuberculin skin testing (TST) has a higher false positive rate in patients who have undergone BCG vaccination, especially in the first few years before immunity wanes. Therefore, IGRA is more specific than TST and is the preferred test in patients with prior BCG vaccination. In patients who have not received the BCG vaccine, both IGRA and TST can be used to test for LTBI. In children < 5 years of age, TST is preferred.

All patients who arrive from countries with a high burden of TB should be screened for TB infection unless there is evidence of a recent screening (e.g., done in the country of origin before departure). Screening typically includes a medical history, physical examination, and IGRA or TST. Chest x-ray is indicated in symptomatic patients and as a follow-up of a positive IGRA/TST. Sputum cultures typically follow if the chest x-ray reveals findings consistent with an active TB infection.
questions.hint: This patient comes from a country with a high burden of tuberculosis (TB) and has close contact with a healthcare professional. He should be screened for latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI).

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. He has type 1 diabetes mellitus. His only medication is insulin. He immigrated from Nepal 4 weeks ago to start his new job as a manager for a software company. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 5 years. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. He has not received any routine childhood vaccinations. The patient appears healthy and well-nourished. He is 172 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 123/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A purified protein derivative (PPD) skin test is performed. Three days later, an induration of 12 mm is noted. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Collect sputum samples for microscopy and nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT)
Administer rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Interferon-γ release assay (IGRA) is a useful first test for the diagnosis of latent tuberculosis (LTBI) and an alternative to the PPD skin test. In addition, IGRA can be used to rule out false-positive results on initial screening (two-step testing strategy) in low TB incidence settings for patients with a low risk of infection in order to avoid overtreatment. However, this patient has an increased risk of infection because he recently immigrated from a country with high TB burden. In addition, he has diabetes mellitus, which is a risk factor for reactivation of LTBI. Therefore, another step in management is more appropriate than confirmatory testing with IGRA.

B) INCORRECT:

Microscopy and NAAT to evaluate for the presence of TB bacilli are an essential part of the initial workup for active TB infection. However, it is not yet known whether the patient has active or latent TB. More diagnostic tests are required before proceeding with the diagnostic pathway of active TB.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with a PPD test showing an induration of ≥ 10 mm are considered TB-positive if they are at high risk, for example, if they have recently (< 5 years) immigrated from a country such as Nepal where TB is endemic. The next question is whether the patient has latent or active TB, which is determined by chest x-ray. If this patient had any symptoms of TB (e.g., fever, cough, night sweats, hemoptysis), he should be put on respiratory isolation prior to any further diagnostics to prevent the spread of the disease.

The threshold for a positive PPD test depends on the individual risk factors of the patient. An induration of ≥ 5 mm is considered positive if one of the following applies: individuals living with HIV, patients under immunosuppression, individuals exposed to TB-positive cases, patients who have undergone organ transplants, and patients with chest x-rays suggestive of a prior TB infection. An induration of ≥ 10 mm is considered TB-positive if one of the following applies: individual who recently (< 5 years) immigrated from a high-prevalence country, individuals who use IV drugs, occupation or residency in high-risk congregate settings (e.g., homeless shelters, prisons), staff of a mycobacteriology laboratory, patients with certain chronic conditions (e.g., diabetes mellitus), and children < 4 years of age. Finally, an induration of ≥ 15 mm is considered positive in all patients without any risk factors, exposure, or symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

A 3-month course of isoniazid and rifapentine is a first-line treatment for latent TB in adult patients without additional risk factors (e.g., HIV infection). However, before any treatment is initiated, it is necessary to rule out active infection which would require a different treatment regimen.

E) INCORRECT:

Rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol (RIPE therapy) is the most common antibiotic regimen for the treatment of active TB. However, it is not yet known whether the patient has active or latent TB. More diagnostic tests are required before initiating treatment.

F) INCORRECT:

Although the BCG vaccine is routinely administered in some countries with a high TB burden, including Nepal, this patient has not received any childhood vaccinations. Therefore, his positive PPD skin test result is rather the result of TB infection than a false test due to BCG vaccination. A positive PPD skin test and a history of recent immigration from a country with a high TB burden make further diagnostic tests necessary.
questions.hint: This patient, who has recently immigrated to the US from a country with high tuberculosis (TB) burden, has a positive PPD skin test. An active TB infection should be ruled out.

questions.text: An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer isoniazid and rifapentine for 3 months
Administer rifampin and isoniazid for 2 months
Obtain CT scan of the chest

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Given this patient's positive PPD skin test, the absence of TB-associated symptoms (e.g., fever, cough, night sweats, hemoptysis), and absence of TB-related findings on chest x-ray (e.g., hilar lymphadenopathy, upper lobe opacification, or cavitation), this patient fulfills the criteria for latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI). All patients with LTBI should receive treatment to prevent reactivation of the disease. Most patients with LTBI qualify for a short regimen of weekly isoniazid and rifapentine therapy for 3 months or daily isoniazid and rifampin therapy for 3 months. An alternative short regimen is 4 months of daily rifampin, which is typically prescribed to patients who do not tolerate isoniazid (INH) or who have been exposed to INH-resistant TB. In patients with HIV, long regimens of 6 or 9 months of isoniazid are the preferred treatment for LTBI (see “Drug regimens for treatment of LTBI” table).

Note that INH is a vitamin B6 antagonist and pyridoxine (vitamin B6) should be considered as adjuvant therapy to prevent side effects such as peripheral neuropathy.

Note that recommendations for the management of LTBI and active TB depend on the country of practice and the local TB burden. The question is designed for a scenario in the US.

B) INCORRECT:

Collecting sputum culture samples (to identify Mycobacterium tuberculosis) is considered the gold standard method for diagnosing active TB. If the x-ray suggested active, pulmonary TB or the patient has symptoms suggestive of TB (e.g., persistent cough for > 2 weeks, fevers) sputum samples would have to be collected next. However, this patient's normal chest x-ray and absence of clinical manifestations of TB make active, pulmonary TB very unlikely. Therefore, the management should focus on the treatment of latent TB infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Rifampin and isoniazid may be used in combination to treat latent TB infection, but this treatment regimen is recommended daily for a period of 3 months. These two medications are also indicated for treating active TB as part of the 6-month RIPE regimen, in which rifampin and isoniazid are given for a 4-month continuation phase following the 2-month intensive phase of rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has a positive PPD skin test and a negative chest x-ray, indicating latent TB infection, which requires treatment to prevent the reactivation of latent TB.

E) INCORRECT:

Although a chest CT scan provides better resolution than a chest x-ray, it is not used for the management of patients with suspected TB; a chest x-ray is less expensive and sensitive enough to diagnose active pulmonary TB.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view; insert: axial CT, lung window) of a patient with postprimary tuberculosis

A thick-walled irregularly shaped cavity (green overlay) in the left lung apex is surrounded by micronodular opacities (examples indicated by dotted lines), which are better seen on the CT image than on the chest radiograph.

The differential diagnosis for a cavitary lung lesion includes both infectious (bacterial, fungal, and occasionally parasitic) and noninfectious (malignant, inflammatory, vascular, and traumatic) etiologies. In postprimary tuberculosis, the apicoposterior segments of the upper lobes and superior segments of the lower lobes are common sites of involvement. A thick-walled cavity accompanied by consolidation or nodular opacities can signify active disease.
questions.hint: This patient's chest x-ray does not show any abnormalities that suggest active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB).

questions.text:
A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of fever, malaise, productive cough, and left-sided chest pain for 2 weeks. During this time, he has woken up to a wet pillow in the morning on multiple occasions and has not been as hungry as usual. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 1 year ago. He currently stays at a homeless shelter. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 22 years. He has a history of intravenous illicit drug use. He drinks 5–6 beers daily. He is receiving combined antiretroviral therapy but sometimes misses doses. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 106/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. Auscultation shows decreased breath sounds over the left base of the lung. There is dullness to percussion on the left lower part of the chest. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14 g/dL


Leukocyte count
5000/mm3



CD4+ T lymphocytes
240/mm3



Serum



 Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL


 γ-Glutamyltransferase (GGT)
65 U/L (N = 5–50)


 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)
15 U/L


 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
19 U/L


 Alkaline phosphatase
40 U/L


 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)
50 U/L


An x-ray of the chest shows a left-sided pleural effusion and hilar lymphadenopathy. Analysis of the pleural fluid shows an effusion with lymphocyte-predominant leukocytosis, high protein, an LDH of 500 U/L, and high adenosine deaminase. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A history of alcoholism combined with a possible hepatitis infection (due to IV drug use) puts the patient at high risk for cirrhosis, which can also cause pleural effusions, malaise, and decreased appetite. However, the absence of other signs such as edema, jaundice, pruritus, and ascites, and the fact that the pleural effusion is exudative rather than transudative, make the diagnosis unlikely. Also, this patient does not have right upper quadrant pain or a firm and enlarged liver on examination, and his lab values (normal AST, ALT, AP) do not indicate hepatocellular damage. His slightly elevated GGT is likely due to alcohol consumption.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) may also present with exudative pleural effusions with lymphocytic predominance, fever, and pleuritic pain. However, it would be unusual to have pleural effusion as the first sign of RA; far more typical is joint pain and swelling. RA in AIDS patients is also quite rare.

C) INCORRECT:

As an IV drug user, the patient is at high risk for infective endocarditis (IE), which may also manifest with fever, night sweats, decreased appetite, pleuritic chest pain, cough, and pleural effusions due to acute cardiac decompensation. However, pleural effusions would be transudative rather than exudative, and further signs of IE would be expected, such as a heart murmur, Janeway lesions, or further signs of CHF (e.g., dyspnea, edema).

D) INCORRECT:

Congestive heart failure (CHF) can also cause pleural effusion and cough, and the history of drug use and HIV point to possible etiologies for CHF. However, fever and night sweats (although they can be attributed to HIV itself), normal cardiovascular examination, exudative nature of the pleuritic fluid (typically transudate in CHF), and the absence of edema and CHF signs on chest x-ray make the diagnosis less likely.

E) INCORRECT:

In a patient with HIV who presents with pulmonary manifestations and poor compliance with HAART, Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia should be considered. However, pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) rarely causes pleural effusions, manifesting instead with progressive dyspnea and diffuse, bilateral ground-glass opacities on chest x-ray. The majority of patients with HIV only develop PCP when the CD4+ count is < 200 /mm3.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP)

Bilateral opacification of the lungs is visible in a perihilar (bat wing or butterfly) distribution (green overlay). This pattern of involvement can be seen in a variety of diseases, including pulmonary edema (cardiogenic and noncardiogenic), pneumonia, inhalational lung injury, pulmonary hemorrhage, pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, and malignancy. Low lung volumes and cardiac silhouette enlargement, which may accompany cardiogenic edema, are not present on this radiograph.

Bilateral perihilar opacification is a common presentation of PCP pneumonia and may have a granular, reticular, or airspace appearance on chest radiography. PCP may also present with lung cysts and pneumothorax. A ground-glass appearance is commonly described on CT. Nodules, cavities, lymphadenopathy, and pleural effusions are uncommon.

F) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism (PE) can also cause exudative pleural effusions, pleuritic pain, and cough. Smoking is a significant risk factor for PE. However, PE usually has a very acute onset. Moreover, the absence of dyspnea, features of DVT (i.e., red, swollen, painful leg), and the normal oxygen saturation make the diagnosis less likely.

G) INCORRECT:

Lung cancer can be seen in smokers and manifest with pleural effusions, cough, and constitutional symptoms such as decreased appetite, night sweats, and fever. This patient's relatively young age, the acute onset of symptoms, a pleural effusion without malignant cells, and the absence of suspicious masses on chest x-ray all make lung cancer unlikely.

H) CORRECT:

Cough, systemic symptoms (fever, decreased appetite, night sweats), and hilar lymphadenopathy in this immunocompromised patient (history of HIV and alcohol use) with a history of potential exposure to tuberculosis (resident at a homeless shelter) are all suggestive of pulmonary tuberculosis. In addition, pleuritic pain (sharp, stabbing) and unilateral lymphocyte-predominant exudative pleural effusion with high levels of adenosine deaminase are highly specific and sensitive markers for tuberculous pleurisy, which typically occurs concurrently with pulmonary tuberculosis.

The analysis of sputum specimens via culture, microscopy, and PCR is the easiest and least invasive way to confirm suspected active pulmonary TB. In patients with HIV, the sensitivity of routine initial microbiological studies may be low and, if available, fluorescent AFB smear microscopy should be performed. If active infection is suspected, patients should be isolated and started on combination therapy consisting of isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol for the first 2 months.
questions.hint: This patient's pleural fluid analysis is consistent with an exudative effusion (pleural fluid LDH > 200 U/L, pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH ratio > 0.6, also see light criteria).

questions.text:
A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of fever and a cough productive of a moderate amount of yellowish sputum. He has had a 6-kg (13-lb) weight loss during this period. He emigrated from the Middle East around 2 years ago. His father died of lung cancer at the age of 54 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 18 years. His only medication is a daily multivitamin. He appears malnourished. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg. Crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.3 g/dL


Leukocyte count
13,200/mm3



Platelet count
330,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
66 mm/h


Serum



 Urea nitrogen
16 mg/dL


 Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL


Urinalysis is within normal limits. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform a high-resolution CT scan of the chest
Collect sputum specimens for acid-fast bacilli smear microscopy, culture, and nucleic acid amplification
Perform transbronchial lung biopsy of the suspected lesion
Start treatment with isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A high-resolution CT scan of the chest could be performed to further evaluate pulmonary processes (e.g., lesions that are potentially cancerous). This patient's chest x-ray in combination with his symptoms and exposure history has already provided sufficient evidence to suspect active TB and further imaging studies are not necessary at this point.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral levofloxacin can be used for outpatient treatment of community-acquired pneumonia. However, the chest x-ray findings in this patient and a potential history of exposure to tuberculosis make pulmonary TB more likely than CAP. Further steps to exclude or confirm active TB should be performed first. Oral levofloxacin does not play a role in the management of TB.

C) CORRECT:

The analysis of sputum specimens is the easiest and least invasive way to confirm suspected active pulmonary TB. Patients with suspected active TB are required to submit 3 sputum specimens, with each one used for culture, acid-fast bacilli smear microscopy, and nucleic acid amplification. The last two tests are useful for rapidly identifying active tuberculosis. Bacterial culture takes 2–6 weeks for results, but is necessary to confirm the diagnosis and test for drug susceptibility. In addition, this patient should be put on airborne precaution measures. Combination therapy consisting of isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol (RIPE therapy) is a treatment of choice for active tuberculosis for the first 2 months of treatment and should be started empirically after sample collection if active infection is highly suspected.

A high-resolution CT scan of the chest could be performed to further evaluate pulmonary processes (e.g., lesions that are potentially cancerous). This patient's chest x-ray in combination with his symptoms and exposure history has already provided sufficient evidence to suspect active TB and further imaging studies are not necessary at this point.

D) INCORRECT:

Transbronchial lung biopsy may be considered in patients with pulmonary lesions that raise suspicion for pulmonary cancer. This patient's x-ray findings (bilateral heterogeneous consolidations with an upper-lobe-predominant distribution, air space nodules, and cavities) are highly indicative of reactivation TB. Transbronchial biopsy is an invasive procedure and therefore not routinely done to confirm TB. Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage could be performed, but it is usually reserved for when suspicion for TB is high and other methods of confirming the diagnosis have failed.

E) INCORRECT:

Combination therapy consisting of isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol is a treatment of choice for active TB for the first 2 months of treatment and is indicated in cases of confirmed active TB and may be started empirically if active infection is suspected. However, before initiating empirical antibiotic therapy, a different step is required to ensure that a definitive diagnosis can be made later on and for prevention of drug resistance during therapy.

F) INCORRECT:

A positive interferon-gamma release assay indicates infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis and is typically used in the diagnosis of latent TB. This patient has findings that indicate active TB. His interferon-gamma release assay would most likely be positive but not provide any additional information.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms (productive cough, systemic symptoms), in addition to a history of immigration from a country with a high burden of tuberculosis (TB) and the patient's findings on chest x-ray (apical cavernous lesion and fibrosis, patchy infiltrates in upper lung fields) raise suspicion for reactivation TB.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has tingling and numbness of his legs for the past 10 days. He has also felt more tired than usual. Three months ago, he was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and started on antituberculosis therapy. He appears pale. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows dry scaly lips and cracks at the corner of the mouth. Neurological examination shows normal muscle strength. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased over the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.4 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 76 μm3. Administration of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While iron deficiency is the most common cause of anemia and could explain the patient's microcytic anemia and cheilosis, it is not associated with neurologic symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Since pyridoxine (vitamin B6) is an essential cofactor in the synthesis of neurotransmitters and heme, patients with a chronic pyridoxine deficiency typically develop sensory peripheral neuropathy and sideroblastic anemia, as seen in this patient. While pyridoxine deficiency is rare in the general population, it is commonly seen in association with isoniazid use in antituberculosis treatment because this drug competes with pyridoxine in neurotransmitter synthesis. To prevent peripheral neuropathy, supplemental pyridoxine should, therefore, be added as an adjuvant treatment to every treatment regimen that includes isoniazid (INH).

INH also commonly causes hepatotoxicity, which manifests with increased serum liver enzyme concentrations and symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and jaundice. Mild hepatotoxicity is usually self-limited, in which case treatment should be continued. More severe involvement is an indication for discontinuing the drug. INH side effects can be remembered by “Injury to Nerves and Hepatocytes”.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immunoglobulins are used to treat diseases such as Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). While GBS can also causes paresthesias of the distal extremities, these are usually mild and accompanied by pain, rather than loss of sensation. Furthermore, in the case of GBS, muscle reflexes would be absent, and ascending, bilateral paralysis would be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin E deficiency may manifest with peripheral neuropathy, but the patient here does not have muscle weakness, ataxia, or hemolytic anemia, which are also typical features of vitamin E deficiency. In addition, this diagnosis is usually associated with conditions that cause fat malabsorption (e.g., pancreatic exocrine insufficiency, cholestatic liver disease), which is not suggested by the patient's history.

E) INCORRECT:

Folate deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia and does not result in sensory neuropathy.

F) INCORRECT:

Although vitamin B12 deficiency may manifest with peripheral neuropathy, it is usually accompanied by further neurological abnormalities (subacute combined degeneration). Additionally, it causes megaloblastic anemia, not microcytic anemia.
questions.hint: This patient's sensory neuropathy (pallhypesthesia, paresthesia) and microcytic anemia (associated with cheilitis) are results of isoniazid toxicity.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. She feels well. She emigrated from India 3 months ago. There is no family history of serious illness. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She is at the 60th percentile for height and weight. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 26/min. Examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.2 g/dL


Leukocyte count
8900/mm3



Platelet count
310,000/mm3



Serum



 Hepatitis B surface antigen
negative


 Hepatitis B surface antibody
positive


 Interferon-γ release assay

positive


An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform CT scan of the chest
Perform acid-fast stain on induced sputum
Administer rifampin, isoniazid, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In a patient with a positive IGRA, a chest CT-scan may be performed to confirm the diagnosis if the patient is symptomatic (e.g., cough, respiratory distress, fever, night sweats) but the chest x-ray is inconclusive (e.g., normal chest x-ray, ill-defined infiltrate, isolated hilar lymphadenopathy). A CT scan of the chest is not required in this patient since she is asymptomatic and the chest x-ray shows no abnormalities.

B) INCORRECT:

Examination of induced sputum via acid-fast microscopy or PCR is indicated when active pulmonary TB is suspected. In an asymptomatic, immunocompetent patient, a normal chest x-ray effectively rules out active pulmonary TB, even if the IGRA is positive. This patient has no evidence of immunodeficiency (e.g., oral candidiasis, HIV positive status); examination of induced sputum is therefore not necessary.

C) CORRECT:

Pharmacological therapy of LTBI is indicated for patients with positive IGRA or TST after active TB has been excluded. The recommended regimens in most patients > 2 years of age are short regimens of weekly isoniazid and rifapentine for 3 months or daily isoniazid and rifampin for 3 months. An alternative short regimen is 4 months of rifampin, which is typically prescribed to patients who do not tolerate isoniazid (INH) or who have been exposed to INH-resistant TB. In patients with HIV or with contraindications to rifamycins, long regimens of 6 or 9 months of isoniazid are the preferred treatment option for LTBI (See “Drug regimens for treatment of LTBI” table).

Because isoniazid (INH) competes with pyridoxine in neurotransmitter synthesis, adjuvant therapy with pyridoxine (vitamin B6) may be indicated to avoid adverse effects (e.g., peripheral neuropathy, sideroblastic anemia).

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with LTBI should be treated to prevent progression from latent to active disease, which occurs in 5–10% of untreated cases.

E) INCORRECT:

A tuberculin skin test is not required since a more specific IGRA has already been performed and returned positive.

F) INCORRECT:

A regimen of rifampin, pyrazinamide, isoniazid, and ethambutol for 2 months followed by a 4 month course of isoniazid and rifampin would be indicated for the treatment of active TB infection. This patient with a positive IFN-γ release assay has latent TB because she is asymptomatic and has a normal chest x-ray; a different step must therefore be considered.
questions.hint: A child from a country with endemic tuberculosis (TB) must be evaluated for TB infection. This child has no symptoms of TB and a chest x-ray with no abnormalities but she has a positive IFN-γ release assay (IGRA), which indicates a latent TB infection. Note that IGRA is usually unaffected by prior BCG vaccines.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man who recently immigrated to the United States from Haiti comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and fatigue. For the past few days, he has also had difficulty lying flat due to trouble breathing. Over the past year, he has had intermittent fever, night sweats, and cough but he has not been seen by a physician for evaluation of these symptoms. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F). An x-ray of the chest is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Elimination of S2 heart sound splitting with inspiration
Head bobbing in synchrony with heart beat
Painless erythematous lesions on palms or soles
Prominent "a" wave on jugular venous pressure tracing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Splitting of the second heart sound (S2) is a physiological finding heard during inspiration. It is caused by the early closure of the aortic valve (A2) in relation to the pulmonary valve (P2) when intrathoracic pressure is decreased. In conditions such as aortic stenosis (AS), ventricular septal defect with Eisenmenger syndrome, and left bundle branch block, elimination of S2 splitting can occur because A2 is delayed and superimposed on P2. Although severe, long-standing aortic stenosis can result in fatigue, dyspnea, orthopnea, and cough (due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema), chronic AS is not associated with fever or night sweats but with symptoms such as syncope, palpitations, and angina. Moreover, an x-ray would not show pericardial calcifications but an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

B) INCORRECT:

Rhythmic nodding or bobbing of the head in synchronicity with the heartbeat is referred to as de Musset sign, a typical feature of chronic aortic regurgitation (AR). AR may present with progressively worsening fatigue, dyspnea, orthopnea, and cough (due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema). However, chronic AR is not associated with fever or night sweats, and an x-ray would not show pericardial calcifications, but rather a prominent aortic root and an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

C) INCORRECT:

Painless erythematous lesions on the palms or soles (Janeway lesions) are highly suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE), which can manifest with dyspnea, fatigue, cough, fever, and night sweats. However, the symptoms of IE have an acute or subacute onset (days to weeks), whereas this patient had fever, night sweats, and a cough for a year before developing dyspnea and fatigue. Moreover, an x-ray would not show pericardial calcifications, and IE is almost always associated with the development of a new heart murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

On a jugular venous pressure tracing, the “a” wave is caused by atrial contraction in late diastole. A prominent “a” wave is a sign of increased atrial contraction pressure due to restricted filling of the right ventricle (e.g., tricuspid valve stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, cardiac tamponade). In constrictive pericarditis, right ventricular filling is only impaired when the elastic limit of the pericardium is reached. As a result, all right ventricular filling rapidly occurs in early diastole, producing a prominent and deep x descent and y descent on venous pressure tracing rather than a prominent “a” wave.
Image Description:

A normal jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform is composed of:
- a wave: atrial contraction
- c wave: tricuspid valve closure
- x descent: atrial relaxation
- v wave: venous refilling of the atria
- y descent: passive filling of right ventricle when the tricuspid valve opens

Common abnormalities of the JVP waveform include:
- Constrictive pericarditis: elevated JVP (due to increased external atrial pressure) with a prominent x (exaggerated atrial relaxation) and y (early rapid ventricular filling) descent
- Cardiac tamponade: elevated JVP (due to increased external atrial pressure), a prominent x descent (exaggerated atrial relaxation), and a blunt or absent y descent (minimal ventricular filling)
- Tricuspid regurgitation: prominent v wave as the blood from the right ventricle regurgitates into the right atrium during ventricular systole (atrial diastole), increasing interatrial pressure and volume
- Tricuspid stenosis: giant a wave due to high right atrial systolic pressure
- Atrial septal defect: v wave ≥ a wave due to the left-to-right shunting of blood
- Third-degree atrioventricular (AV) block: cannon a waves due to the loss of AV synchronization and contraction of the atria against a closed tricuspid valve
- Atrial fibrillation: absent a waves due to ineffective contraction of the atria

E) CORRECT:

Normally, the decrease in intrathoracic pressure during inspiration expands the compliant right ventricle, resulting in a decrease in jugular venous pressure. In constrictive pericarditis, compliance of the right ventricle is decreased and the right ventricle fails to expand during inspiration. This, alongside a possible increase in baseline jugular venous pressure in constrictive pericarditis due to restricted right ventricular filling during late diastole, leads to an increase in jugular venous pressure during inspiration, and therefore, jugular venous distention on inspiration. This phenomenon, which is called Kussmaul sign, can also be seen in patients with restrictive cardiomyopathy and right atrial or ventricular tumors. Management options for constrictive pericarditis include NSAIDs, colchicine, glucocorticoids, pericardiectomy, and treatment of the underlying condition (e.g., antitubercular or immunomodulatory therapy).

In cardiac tamponade without underlying pericarditis (e.g., traumatic hemopericardium), the jugular venous pressure is increased as a result of impaired right ventricular filling. However, the right ventricle is still compliant and a decrease in intrathoracic pressure can be transmitted to the right ventricle across the fluid-filled pericardial sac. Kussmaul sign would not be expected in traumatic cardiac tamponade.

F) INCORRECT:

A crescendo-decrescendo (diamond-shaped) systolic ejection murmur best heard in the second right intercostal space is a common finding in aortic stenosis (AS). While severe, long-standing AS can result in chest pain, fatigue, dyspnea, orthopnea, and cough (due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema), fever and night sweats are not commonly seen. Finally, symptoms such as syncope, angina, and palpitations are expected in chronic AS, and x-ray would show an enlarged cardiac silhouette rather than the pericardial calcifications seen here.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.
questions.hint: New-onset dyspnea, orthopnea, and fatigue alongside pericardial thickening and calcifications on x-ray indicate constrictive pericarditis. In this patient with an immigration history from an endemic region and a prolonged history of night sweats, fever, and cough, the most likely etiology of constrictive pericarditis is tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has had numbness and tingling of his legs for the past 10 days. Three months ago, he was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and started on antituberculosis therapy. Examination shows dry scaly lips and cracks at the corner of the mouth. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased over the lower extremities. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.4 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 76 μm3. Administration of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While iron deficiency is the most common cause of anemia and could explain the patient's microcytic anemia and cheilosis, it is not associated with neurologic symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin E deficiency may present with peripheral neuropathy (tingling and decreased sensation to pinprick/light touch), but the patient here does not have muscle weakness, ataxia, or hemolytic anemia, which are also typical features of vitamin E deficiency. In addition, this diagnosis is usually associated with conditions that cause fat malabsorption (e.g., pancreatic exocrine insufficiency, cholestatic liver disease), which is not suggested by the patient's history.

C) INCORRECT:

Folate deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia – not microcytic anemia. It also does not result in sensory neuropathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Although vitamin B12 deficiency may present with peripheral neuropathy, as seen in this patient, it is usually accompanied by further neurological abnormalities (subacute combined degeneration). Additionally, it causes megaloblastic anemia, not microcytic anemia.

E) CORRECT:

Since pyridoxine (vitamin B6) is an essential cofactor in the synthesis of neurotransmitters and heme, patients with a chronic pyridoxine deficiency typically present with sensory peripheral neuropathy and hypochromic, microcytic anemia (sideroblastic anemia), as seen here. While vitamin B6 deficiency is rare in the general population, it is commonly seen in association with isoniazid (INH) use in antituberculosis treatment, because INH competes with pyridoxine in neurotransmitter synthesis. To prevent peripheral neuropathy, supplemental pyridoxine should therefore be added to every treatment regimen that includes INH.

F) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immunoglobulins are used to treat diseases such as Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). While GBS can also cause paresthesias of the distal extremities, these are usually mild and accompanied by pain, rather than frank loss of sensation. Furthermore, in the case of GBS, muscle reflexes would be absent and bilateral ascending paralysis would be expected.
questions.hint: This patient's sensory neuropathy and microcytic anemia are the result of isoniazid toxicity.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of lower back pain, night sweats, and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss during the past 4 weeks. She has rheumatoid arthritis treated with adalimumab. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Physical examination shows tenderness over the T10 and L1 spinous processes. Passive extension of the right hip causes pain in the right lower quadrant. The patient's symptoms are most likely caused by an organism with which of the following virulence factors?

choices.text: Surface glycolipids that prevent phagolysosome fusion
Proteins that bind to the Fc region of immunoglobulin G

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A polysaccharide capsule that prevents phagocytosis is found in P. aeruginosa and Salmonella spp., which can cause osteomyelitis. However, pseudomonal osteomyelitis typically affects intravenous drug users and Salmonella osteomyelitis typically occurs in patients with sickle cell disease. These risk factors are not reported in this patient. The presence of constitutional symptoms such as night sweats and weight loss as well as the history of treatment with a TNF-alpha inhibitor suggest a different pathogen.

B) CORRECT:

The cord factor is a glycolipid in the cell wall of M. tuberculosis that inhibits phagosome-lysosome fusion and prevents lysis of phagocytosed mycobacteria. It has a synergistic effect with sulfatides, a sulfolipid virulence factor in M. tuberculosis that inhibits phagosome-lysosome fusion. This allows M. tuberculosis to survive in the phagosomes of macrophages. Cord factor also causes virulent M. tuberculosis bacilli to grow in a serpentine cord-like pattern and promotes the formation of granulomas by stimulating the release of TNF-alpha.

TNF-α plays an important role in the sequestration of M. tuberculosis in granulomas; inhibition of TNF-α results in the breakdown of granulomas and the release of mycobacteria, causing reactivation of latent TB. Patients receiving treatment with TNF-alpha inhibitors should be tested for infection with M. tuberculosis.

C) INCORRECT:

The virulence factor exotoxin A, which is produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, impairs protein synthesis by inactivating EEF2. P. aeruginosa is a common cause of osteomyelitis in intravenous drug users. The presence of constitutional symptoms such as night sweats and weight loss as well as the history of treatment with a TNF-alpha inhibitor suggest a different pathogen.

D) INCORRECT:

The virulence factor protein A, which is produced by Staphylococcus aureus, binds to the Fc region of immunoglobulin G, thereby preventing opsonization and phagocytosis. S. aureus is the most common cause of osteomyelitis. However, the presence of constitutional symptoms such as night sweats and weight loss as well as the history of treatment with a TNF-alpha inhibitor suggest a different pathogen.

E) INCORRECT:

IgA protease is a virulence factor that cleaves immunoglobulin A, which allows pathogens to adhere to mucous membranes. It is produced by various bacteria, including S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and Neisseria species. Infection with N. gonorrhoeae can lead to septic arthritis and osteomyelitis of the spine, causing hip or lower back pain. However, this patient's constitutional symptoms following treatment with a TNF-alpha inhibitor suggest infection with a different microorganism.
questions.hint: Fever, lower back pain, focal spinal tenderness, and a positive psoas sign are characteristic of vertebral osteomyelitis. Constitutional symptoms such as weight loss and fever as well as the history of treatment with a TNF-alpha inhibitor (adalimumab) suggest Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of coughing, fatigue, night sweats, and 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. His cough is productive of blood-stained sputum. He works as an engineer and traveled to South Africa 2 months ago for a site inspection of a mine. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He appears ill with generalized wasting. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 122/84 mm Hg. Respiratory examination shows dullness to percussion over the right lower lobe and crackles on auscultation. Chest x-ray shows consolidation in the right lower lobe and ipsilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Microscopy of the sputum shows acid-fast bacteria. Antibiotic therapy is initiated. At his follow-up visit 1 month later, the patient reports bilateral progressive, painless, blurred vision and an inability to distinguish between red and green. An adverse effect of which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of this patient's ocular symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rifampin is used in the intensive and continuation phases of tuberculosis treatment. Common adverse effects of rifampin include flu-like symptoms, hepatotoxicity, and a characteristic harmless orange discoloration of body fluids (e.g., urine, and tears). This drug does not cause optic neuritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Pyrazinamide is used in the intensive phase of tuberculosis treatment. Common adverse effects include hyperuricemia, hepatotoxicity, and gastrointestinal disturbances (e.g., vomiting). This drug does not cause optic neuritis.

C) CORRECT:

Ethambutol is used in conjunction with other agents to treat active tuberculosis during the initial phase of therapy. Optic neuritis is an important adverse effect of ethambutol and can manifest with decreased visual acuity, central and peripheral scotomas, and dyschromatopsia. Although its mechanism is unknown, the risk of ethambutol-induced optic neuritis increases with dose. Individuals receiving ethambutol should have ophthalmic evaluations performed at baseline and periodically during treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Isoniazid (INH) is used in the intensive and continuation phases of tuberculosis treatment. Liver injury is a common adverse effect of INH, usually causing mildly elevated transaminases and, more rarely, fulminant hepatitis. Although INH can cause optic neuritis, it is a rare adverse effect that is more likely to develop with a different antibiotic.

E) INCORRECT:

Pyridoxine is an essential cofactor in the synthesis of neurotransmitters and heme. Because it competes with isoniazid (INH) in neurotransmitter synthesis, the drugs are commonly used together in antituberculosis therapy. Thus, pyridoxine should be used as an adjuvant in every regimen that includes INH. However, supplementation with pyridoxine does not cause optic neuritis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms of optic neuritis (blurred vision, dyschromatopsia) following the initiation of tuberculosis treatment. Irreversible blindness may develop with continued use of this drug.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician for a pre-employment examination. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. A screening blood test is performed in which peptides are added to the sample to stimulate in vitro production of interferon-gamma, which is then measured using an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. This test is most likely to be helpful in diagnosing infection with which of the following pathogens?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The current standard for diagnosis of HIV is a combination antigen/antibody test, which detects both HIV antigen (p24) and anti-HIV antibodies. There are also antibody-only tests available that detect antibodies via ELISA, as well as HIV-1/HIV-2 antibody differentiation immunoassays to identify the HIV subtype. Western blot can be used to detect specific serum proteins (HIV antigens). HIV is not diagnosed via IGRA.

B) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive and coagulase-positive coccus that causes an array of infections. However, S. aureus screening is done via nose, throat, and anal swabs that are then cultured for S. aureus and assayed to detect drug-resistant variants (e.g., MRSA). S. aureus cannot be detected via IGRA.

C) INCORRECT:

The hepatitis B virus can be transmitted sexually, parenterally, or perinatally and can cause acute or chronic inflammation of the liver. However, it is usually diagnosed via enzyme immunoassay (EIA) or enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) detection of viral antigens (HBsAg, HBeAg, and HBcAg) or their corresponding antibodies (anti‑HBs, anti‑HBe, and anti‑HBc IgM) in serum. PCR can be used to detect HBV DNA in the serum as well. HBV is not diagnosed via IGRA.

D) CORRECT:

The IGRA test for latent Mycobacterium tuberculosis relies on the fact that IFN-γ is released by T lymphocytes when they are exposed to mycobacterial antigens. IGRA is preferred in patients who have received Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG) vaccine, as the test is not dependent on the patient's vaccination status (the PPD test may show a false positive in these patients). If an IGRA test is positive, further evaluation for active TB (e.g. chest x-ray) is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Clostridioides difficile (C. difficile) is a gram-positive, rod-shaped bacillus that causes antibiotic-associated diarrhea (C. difficile colitis). It is diagnosed via enzyme immunoassay (EIA) for glutamate dehydrogenase antigen or for C. difficile toxins A and B, bacterial culture of C. difficile, or PCR for C. difficile toxin genes. IGRA, however, is not utilized for diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Legionella pneumophila is a gram-negative rod that causes Legionnaires' disease and Pontiac fever. Various diagnostic methods can be used to detect the organism, including urine antigen testing, silver staining of respiratory secretions, and bacterial culture (using buffered iron and cysteine charcoal yeast extract agar). L. pneumophila is not diagnosed via IGRA.
questions.hint: An interferon-γ release assay (IGRA) was the test performed here.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of increasing shortness of breath on exertion, dry cough, and fatigue. He has not had any fevers or night sweats. He worked in a glass manufacturing factory for 15 years and retired 2 years ago. Pulmonary examination shows diffuse crackles bilaterally. An x-ray of the chest shows well-defined calcification of the rims of hilar lymph nodes and scattered nodules in both upper lung fields. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Malignant mesothelioma is associated with asbestosis, a type of pneumoconiosis that could manifest with features of progressive pulmonary fibrosis (e.g., dyspnea, dry cough, fatigue, fine crackles). However, asbestosis predominantly affects the lower lobes (unlike this patient with upper lobe nodules), is typically associated with pleural plaques, and usually does not affect the hilar lymph nodes. Moreover, asbestosis is typically seen in individuals working in shipbuilding, roofing, or plumbing industries. Silicosis is associated with an increased risk of lung parenchymal malignancy but not mesothelioma.

B) INCORRECT:

Invasive aspergillosis is an infection caused by Aspergillus, which is characterized by severe pneumonia and septicemia. Although underlying lung disease is a risk factor for chronic pulmonary aspergillosis (which can manifest as an aspergilloma, an aspergillus nodule, or cavitary/fibrosing aspergillosis), invasive aspergillosis is primarily associated with immunosuppression (e.g., HIV infection, primary immunodeficiency disorders, immunosuppressive therapy, malignancies), not silicosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Pneumocystis pneumonia is a type of interstitial pneumonia caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii, it is mainly associated with immunosuppression (e.g., HIV infection, primary immunodeficiency disorders, immunosuppressive therapy, malignancies). An immunocompetent patient with silicosis is unlikely to develop Pneumocystis pneumonia.

D) INCORRECT:

Spontaneous pneumothorax is typically associated with smoking, emphysematous lung disease, and tall, thin stature. Pleural involvement in silicosis can also lead to spontaneous pneumothorax. Although some cases have been reported in patients with silicosis involving the pleura, another complication is more commonly associated with this disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism is typically associated with prothrombotic states such as prolonged immobilization (e.g., postoperatively), nephrotic syndrome, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, polycythemia, advanced malignancy, and hereditary thrombosis syndromes (e.g., factor V Leiden deficiency, protein C or protein S deficiency). Silicosis is not a prothrombotic condition.

F) CORRECT:

Patients with advanced silicosis are at increased risk of pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) because silica disrupts phagolysosomes and impairs macrophage function, and consequently, the pulmonary immune response. Annual TB skin testing is therefore recommended in patients with advanced silicosis. Further complications associated with this disease include lung cancer, cor pulmonale, and rheumatoid arthritis (Caplan syndrome).
questions.hint: In patients who worked as glass-factory workers, clinical features of interstitial lung disease (e.g., progressive dyspnea, dry cough, fatigue, fine crackles) with calcification of the rims of hilar lymph nodes (eggshell calcification) and predominant involvement of the upper lobes suggest silicosis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. His most recent examination 2 years ago included purified protein derivative (PPD) skin testing and showed no abnormalities. He is a retired physician and recently came back from rural China where he completed a voluntary service at a local healthcare center. A PPD skin test is performed. Three days later, an induration of 12 mm is noted. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. He is started on a drug that inhibits the synthesis of mycolic acid. This patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following adverse effects?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Optic neuropathy manifesting as red-green color blindness is a common side effect of ethambutol, an antimycobacterial drug that prevents bacterial cell wall synthesis by inhibiting arabinosyltransferase. Ethambutol is used for treatment of active tuberculosis during the initial phase of therapy in conjunction with other agents. It is not indicated as monotherapy for latent tuberculosis. Optic neuropathy may rarely be caused by isoniazid, but this patient is at greater risk for a different adverse effect.

B) CORRECT:

Liver injury is a common adverse effect of isoniazid (INH), which in most cases is evidenced only by mildly elevated transaminases. However, a small number of patients develop fulminant hepatitis; older age is a major risk factor. INH is also associated with vitamin B6 deficiency (which can manifest with sideroblastic anemia and peripheral neuropathy), cytochrome P450 inhibition, and drug-induced lupus erythematosus. A small proportion of patients may also experience optic neuropathy and impaired color vision. Thus, concurrent administration of pyridoxine (vitamin B6) is often recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperuricemia is a side effect seen in patients taking pyrazinamide, an antimycobacterial drug whose exact mechanism of action has not been elucidated. Pyrazinamide is used for treatment of active tuberculosis during the initial phase of therapy in conjunction with other agents. It is not indicated as monotherapy for latent tuberculosis. Hepatotoxicity is another common adverse effect of pyrazinamide.

D) INCORRECT:

Cytochrome P-450 induction is a side effect of rifampin, an antimycobacterial drug that obstructs bacterial protein synthesis by inhibiting bacterial DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, thereby preventing transcription. Rifampin is used for treatment of tuberculosis (active and latent) as well as nontuberculous mycobacterial diseases. Further adverse effects include flu-like symptoms, and harmless orange discoloration of body fluids (e.g., urine, tears).

E) INCORRECT:

Nephrotoxicity is a side effect seen in streptomycin, an aminoglycoside that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome. Streptomycin is used as second-line therapy for active tuberculosis in combination with other antimycobacterial agents. It is not indicated as monotherapy for latent tuberculosis. Further adverse effects include ototoxicity and vestibulotoxicity.
questions.hint: This patient's positive PPD skin test indicates exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. In the absence of clinical symptoms and a normal chest x-ray, the patient most likely has latent tuberculosis. Inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis is the mechanism of action of isoniazid.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man who emigrated from Sri Lanka 2 years ago comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of fever, cough, and a 6-kg (13-lb) weight loss. He appears ill. An x-ray of the chest shows patchy infiltrates in the upper lung fields with a cavernous lesion at the right apex. A CT-guided biopsy of the lesion is obtained. A photomicrograph of the biopsy specimen is shown. Which of the following surface antigens is most likely to be found on the cells indicated by the arrowhead?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CD8 is an antigen found on cytotoxic T lymphocytes. It acts as a coreceptor to the T-cell receptor when communicating with antigen-presenting cells. CD8 is not expressed on macrophages.

B) INCORRECT:

CD40L is a ligand on T helper cells that binds to CD40, which induces B cell activation and Ig class switching. While the CD40 molecule is present on macrophages, CD40L is only present on T helper cells.

C) INCORRECT:

CD56 is a molecule expressed on natural killer cells. While there is some evidence that natural killer cells may play a role in host defense against M. tuberculosis, the cell indicated in the image is not a natural killer cell. Macrophages do not express CD56.

D) CORRECT:

CD14 is a cell surface marker that can be detected via immunophenotyping and is strongly expressed on macrophages. After exposure to TB, activated alveolar macrophages phagocytose TB bacteria but are unable to lyse them, allowing TB to remain dormant for months or years before reactivation. Macrophages therefore play a key role in the pathophysiology of Mycobacteria tuberculosis infection.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

A large epithelioid granuloma containing several multinucleated giant cells (Langhans cells; black arrowhead) is visible. Dense collections of leukocytes (examples indicated by black arrows) can be seen in the surrounding area. Necrotic areas (yellow overlay) are also visible.

These findings are characteristic of a caseating tuberculous granuloma.

E) INCORRECT:

CD34 is a protein that is found on hematopoietic stem cells. There is no indication that this patient has a hematopoietic or vascular disease. Moreover, CD34 is also not found on macrophages.

F) INCORRECT:

CD3 is an antigen found on T lymphocytes. While T lymphocytes can destroy phagocytosed M. tuberculosis, the arrow is pointing to an epithelioid macrophage, not a T lymphocyte. CD3 is not found on macrophages.
questions.hint: This patient immigrated from an area with high tuberculosis (TB) prevalence. His cough, fever, and weight loss suggest TB infection, and his chest x-ray findings (apical cavernous lesion, patchy infiltrates in the upper lung fields) are consistent with reactivated pulmonary TB. The arrow marks a Langhans giant cell, which is composed of fused epithelioid macrophage cells. These giant cells phagocytose mycobacteria in TB infection.

questions.text: A researcher is studying a new antituberculosis drug. In the laboratory, the drug has been shown to be effective against mycobacteria located within phagolysosomes of macrophages, but it is also significantly less effective against extracellular tuberculoid bacteria. The characteristics of this drug are most similar to which of the following agents?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Isoniazid prevents mycobacterial cell wall synthesis by inhibiting the production of mycolic acid, an essential component of the cell wall. Unlike the drug being studied in this case, isoniazid is equally active in both intracellular and extracellular environments. Common side effects include hepatotoxicity and peripheral neuropathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Rifampin exerts its bactericidal activity by preventing mycobacterial protein synthesis through inhibition of mycobacterial DNA-dependent RNA polymerase. Unlike the drug being studied in this case, rifampin is equally active in both intracellular and extracellular environments. Common side effects include orange discoloration of body fluids, flu-like symptoms, and hepatotoxicity.

C) INCORRECT:

Ethambutol prevents mycobacterial cell wall synthesis by inhibiting the enzyme arabinosyltransferase. Unlike the drug being studied in this case, ethambutol acts on bacteria equally well in extracellular and intracellular environments. A common and potentially serious side effect of its use is optic neuritis.

D) CORRECT:

Pyrazinamide is most similar to this experimental drug. Pyrazinamide is an essential anti-tuberculous drug that is activated into pyrazinoic acid. This conversion is best achieved at an acidic pH, such as that found within host macrophage phagolysosomes. As a result, pyrazinamide drug is most effective against intracellular mycobacteria, as these organisms are also located within the acidic phagolysosome that contains the activated drug.

E) INCORRECT:

Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside that binds to the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome and prevents protein synthesis. Unlike the drug being studied in this case, streptomycin is equally active in both intracellular and extracellular environments. Like other aminoglycosides, it is both nephrotoxic and ototoxic.
questions.hint: Common adverse effects of the drug in question are hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fevers for 2 weeks. She works as a nurse and recently returned from a charity work trip to India, where she worked in a medically-underserved rural community. A tuberculin skin test 3 months ago prior to her trip showed an induration of 3 mm. Physical examination is unremarkable. An x-ray of the chest shows right-sided hilar lymphadenopathy. A sputum culture shows acid-fast bacilli. Which of the following immunologic processes most likely occurred first?

choices.text: Transportation of bacterial peptides to regional lymph nodes
Formation of a nodular tubercle in the lung
Replication of bacteria within alveolar macrophages
Production of interferon-gamma by T-helper cells
Migration of T-helper cells to the lungs

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transportation of bacterial peptides to regional lymph nodes is carried out by antigen presenting cells (APCs), which migrate to the secondary lymphoid organs and interact with class II antigens on naive T-helper cells, resulting in T-helper cell proliferation. Subsequently, these T cells migrate to the lungs and contribute to granuloma formation (type 4 hypersensitivity reaction). However, transportation of bacterial peptides to regional lymph nodes requires between 1–3 days and would not be the first of the processes listed here to occur in TB infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Formation of a nodular tubercle (granuloma) in the lung is an important part of the human defense mechanism against mycobacterial infection. These granulomas contain M. tuberculosis-infected macrophages as well as epithelioid cells and Langhans giant cells, which are surrounded by T-helper cells. The center of these granulomas is a cellular necrotic region (caseous granuloma). Granulomas can take between days to weeks to form and would not be the first of the processes listed here to occur in TB infection.

C) CORRECT:

Replication of Mycobacterium tuberculosis within the alveolar macrophages is the first of the processes listed here to occur in primary TB infection. Mycobacteria are transmitted from person to person via airborne droplets. Once inside the alveoli, the bacteria are ingested by alveolar macrophages and those bacteria that successfully escape the phagolysosome fusion then begin to replicate within the macrophages. After replication, the following sequence in mycobacterial infection is transportation of bacterial peptides to the regional lymph nodes, migration of T-helper cells to the lungs, production of interferon-gamma by T-helper cells, and formation of a nodular tubercle in the lung.

D) INCORRECT:

Fusion of phagolysosomes is required to destroy phagocytosed pathogens. M. tuberculosis inhibits this process by producing glycolipids called sulfatides, which interfere with the signaling processes that label phagosomes for digestion, ensuring intracellular survival of the bacteria. However, mycobacteria are only known to inhibit phagolysosome fusion within macrophages, not neutrophils. Fusion of phagolysosomes in neutrophils would, therefore, not be an immunologic process in TB infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Production of interferon gamma (IFN-γ) by T-helper cells amplifies the conversion of naive T cells to memory T cells in mycobacterial infection and activates macrophages (which become epithelioid cells), enhancing phagocytosis. However, the full activation of T-helper cells requires between 4–5 days and would not be the first of the processes listed here to occur in TB infection.

F) INCORRECT:

Migration of T-helper cells to the lungs occurs when M. tuberculosis-infected alveolar macrophages disseminate to the lymph nodes and interact with class II antigens on naive T-helper cells. This initiates IL-2 secretion, which stimulates migration of T-helper cells to the lungs, ultimately contributing to granuloma formation (type 4 hypersensitivity reaction). However, the full activation of T-helper cells requires between 4–5 days and would not be the first of the processes listed here to occur in TB infection.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms and clinical findings (fever, sputum with acid-fast bacilli), in addition to her recent travel history, are suggestive of a primary tuberculosis infection.

questions.text: A previously healthy 67-year-old man comes to the physician for routine health maintenance evaluation. He works at a community center and volunteers at a local homeless shelter. A tuberculin skin test shows an induration of 14 mm. An x-ray of the chest is normal. Treatment with an antimycobacterial drug is initiated. Two months later, he has numbness and burning over both feet and an unsteady gait. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to light touch extending from the soles of the feet to the mid-shin bilaterally. This patient's condition is most likely to result in which of the following?

choices.text: Impaired breakdown of glucose to ATP

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Pyridoxine deficiency causes impaired synthesis of neurotransmitters, as pyridoxine is an important cofactor for multiple enzymes, including those that take part in the synthesis of GABA, serotonin, epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine. Decreased levels of GABA can cause hyperirritability and seizures. In addition, vitamin B6 is an important cofactor of the enzyme cystathionine synthase, which is needed for the conversion of homocysteine to cysteine. When this enzyme is impaired, (e.g., during isoniazid treatment), homocysteine is increasingly metabolized to S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) via methionine synthase. SAM inhibits the synthesis of sphingolipids and myelin, which can lead to irreversible nerve damage.

Dietary vitamin B6 deficiency is rare, but can occur in patients with certain risk factors such as advanced age, as seen here, as well as obesity, pregnancy, preeclampsia, eclampsia, and malabsorptive states. Pyridoxine deficiency is more commonly associated with medication interactions that impair vitamin B6 metabolism, such as isoniazid, penicillamine, and hydralazine.

B) INCORRECT:

Intracellular accumulation of sorbitol is the mechanism of action of diabetic neuropathy, which can result in paresthesias, loss of sensation in a stocking pattern, and an unsteady gait due to impaired proprioception (sensory ataxia). However, isoniazid is not associated with sorbitol accumulation.

C) INCORRECT:

Segmental demyelination of peripheral axons is seen in certain peripheral neuropathies such as Guillain-Barré syndrome, chronic inflammatory demyelinating neuropathy, metachromatic leukodystrophy, and type 1 Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.
