These peripheral neuropathies can also result in paresthesias, loss of light touch sensation, and an unsteady gait due to impaired proprioception (sensory ataxia). However, the peripheral neuropathy caused by pyridoxine deficiency is the result of a degenerative axonal neuropathy and not a demyelinating neuropathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Deficiency of ATP due to an impaired breakdown of glucose is the mechanism of neuropathy in patients with thiamine deficiency (dry beriberi), because thiamine is an essential cofactor for the enzymes pyruvate dehydrogenase and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase. Isoniazid causes a deficiency of pyridoxine (vitamin B6), not thiamine (vitamin B1).

E) INCORRECT:

Degeneration of the dorsal column is seen in subacute combined degeneration (SCD), which is caused by vitamin B12 deficiency and can manifest with decreased light touch sensation as well as an unsteady gait due to impaired proprioception (sensory ataxia). Peripheral neuropathy due to vitamin B12 deficiency could also explain the paresthesias in this patient. However, while long-term use of metformin can cause vitamin B12 deficiency, isoniazid is not known to cause it.
questions.hint: Isoniazid is a commonly used monotherapy for latent tuberculosis. Adverse effects of isoniazid include peripheral polyneuropathy due to pyridoxine deficiency.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician for a 1-month history of fever, chest pain with deep breathing, and a 4-kg (9 lb) weight loss. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). An x-ray of the chest shows a subpleural nodule in the right lower lobe with right hilar lymphadenopathy. Microscopic examination of a right hilar lymph node biopsy specimen shows several granulomas with acellular cores. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While Hodgkin lymphoma is associated with hilar lymphadenopathy and subacute manifestation of B symptoms (fever, weight loss), it would not cause a pulmonary nodule and it is histologically characterized by Reed-Sternberg cells, not granulomas with acellular cores.

B) CORRECT:

In primary tuberculosis infection, alveolar macrophages phagocytize the TB organism, and immune cells surround the engulfed organism to form a caseating granuloma. The caseating granuloma, which has an acellular, necrotic core, forms the Ghon focus of the Ghon complex. This complex is usually found in the middle or lower lobes of the lung. Although primary tuberculosis is often asymptomatic, patients may present with fever, weight loss, and pleuritic chest pain when a subpleural nodule is present.
Image Description:

Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic berylliosis is more often associated with dyspnea and cough than chest pain, and a chest radiograph would show features of interstitial lung disease predominantly in the upper lobe, not a solitary lung nodule in the lower lobe. Though berylliosis does manifest with enlarged hilar lymph nodes, it is associated with noncaseating granulomas, so cellular, rather than acellular, cores would be seen.

D) INCORRECT:

Although miliary tuberculosis can exhibit caseating granulomas and manifest with fever, chest pain, and weight loss, a chest x-ray would show diffuse reticulonodular opacification with a “millet seed” appearance, not a solitary pulmonary nodule.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with miliary tuberculosis

Innumerable small nodules (∼ 2 mm in size; examples indicated by green overlay) are distributed diffusely throughout the parenchyma of both lungs. A laterally circumscribed convexity (red outline) representing adenopathy overlies the region of the right descending pulmonary artery.

A miliary pattern may be seen in several conditions, among them tuberculosis, fungal infections, and metastatic disease. The clinical presentation and associated imaging findings provide information essential to the differential diagnosis of miliary lung nodules.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic silicosis is more likely to manifest with cough, dyspnea, and multiple small upper lobe fibrotic lesions than with fever, chest pain, and a solitary nodule in a lower lung lobe. It is not associated with caseating granulomas, although it does predispose patients to the development of tuberculosis and lung cancer.
Image Description:

Chest X-ray (lateral view) of an elderly male patient with progressive dyspnea and a history of working with sandblasting equipment for a number of years

Extensive heterogeneous, patchy, partially confluent opacities are visible, particularly in the upper lung fields (green overlay).

Those findings are consistent with silicosis (which, given the patient's history, is the most likely diagnosis).

F) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary sarcoidosis is associated with fever, weight loss, chest pain, and hilar lymph node enlargement. However, patients with sarcoidosis typically have bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and interstitial opacification rather than unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and a solitary pulmonary nodule. In addition, sarcoidosis is histologically typified by the formation of noncaseating granulomas, in which granulomas with cellular, rather than acellular, cores would be visualized.
questions.hint: The combination of a subpleural granulomatous lesion and enlarged hilar lymph node on the same side is referred to as a Ghon complex. In most patients, this lesion will eventually calcify to form a Ranke complex.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician with a 2-month history of fever, night sweats, and a cough productive of white sputum. He lives in New York and is currently homeless. He uses intravenous heroin several times a week. Three months ago he was admitted to the hospital for aspiration pneumonia. His dad passed away at the age of 54 because of “a bad heart condition.” His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F) and respirations are 22/min. Physical examination shows coarse crackles in the left upper posterior lung field. An x-ray of the chest shows a cavitary lesion with calcification in the left upper lobe. Which of the following is the most likely source of his pulmonary findings?

choices.text: Exposure to contaminated hot water tanks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aspiration of oral flora is a common cause of aspiration pneumonia, which can manifest with fever and cough. However, symptoms are usually acute and severe. Moreover, radiologic studies of aspiration pneumonia classically show infiltrates in the dependent parts of the lung, not a single cavitary lesion in the upper lobe.

B) INCORRECT:

Exposure to contaminated hot water tanks is a common source of Legionella pneumophila, which causes Legionnaire disease. Legionnaire disease can manifest with fever and cough, but symptoms are usually acute and severe. Moreover, the radiographic features of Legionnaire disease classically include interstitial infiltrates in the lungs, not cavitary lesions.

C) CORRECT:

The patient's findings (fever, night sweats, productive cough, and a pulmonary cavitary lesion on chest x-ray) and history of immunocompromise due to homelessness and IV drug use are consistent with reactivation of latent tuberculosis infection. The initial focus of infection with M. tuberculosis, the Ghon complex, is usually contained by the host's immune response, and the bacteria may remain dormant in granulomas for many years. During periods of relative immunodeficiency, the latent bacilli become active and proliferate, causing reactivation tuberculosis, which usually manifests with a cavitary lesion in the apical segments of the lung.
Image Description:

Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

D) INCORRECT:

Embolization of bacterial vegetations to the lungs can occur in individuals with bacterial endocarditis, which can be seen in patients with a history of IV drug use and manifest with fever, cough, and night sweats. However, symptoms are usually acute and severe. Moreover, radiologic studies (e.g., CT pulmonary angiography) classically show an intraluminal filling defect of the pulmonary arteries; the presence of a wedge-shaped infarction with pleural effusion is a highly specific finding. A single cavitary lesion in the upper lobe, which can be seen in this patient, would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Contact with pigeon droppings in combination with pulmonary findings can point to infection with Histoplasma capsulatum and cryptococcal species, which can cause histoplasmosis and cryptococcosis, respectively. Pulmonary cryptococcosis can manifest with cavitary lesions on chest x-ray, but lesions are typically multiple nodular instead of singular. Calcification would not be expected. Histoplasmosis classically manifests with parenchymal infiltrates and/or hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy on radiography, rather than the cavitary lesion seen in this patient. Moreover, H. capsulatum is predominantly endemic to the Mississippi and Ohio River valleys.
questions.hint: The pathogen isolated from this patient's sputum will likely grow on Loewenstein-Jensen agar.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of fever and productive cough with blood-tinged sputum. She has also had a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss during the same time period. Examination shows enlarged cervical lymph nodes. An x-ray of the chest shows a 2.5-cm pulmonary nodule in the right upper lobe. A biopsy specimen of the lung nodule shows caseating granulomas with surrounding multinucleated giant cells. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's pulmonary nodule?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

IgE-mediated mast cell activation is characteristic of type I hypersensitivity reactions. A type I hypersensitivity reaction manifesting with cough would be seen in allergic asthma. However, asthma is not associated with hemoptysis, weight loss, and caseating granuloma formation. In addition, granuloma formation in patients with tuberculosis is not associated with a type I hypersensitivity reaction.

B) CORRECT:

Delayed T cell-mediated reactions are characteristic of type IV hypersensitivity, which is seen in infection with mycobacteria. Following infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the pathogen is phagocytosed and persists in alveolar macrophages. CD4+ T cells (T helper cells) recognize mycobacterial antigens that are presented by macrophages. CD4+ T cells then differentiate into Th1 cells, which release IFN-γ to recruit and activate macrophages. Activated macrophages differentiate into epithelioid cells, which aggregate and fuse into multinucleated giant cells (Langhans giant cells). Aggregation of epithelioid cells, multinucleated giant cells, and CD4+ T cells around a necrotic cellular center leads to the formation of caseating granulomas, which are an important part of the human defense mechanism against mycobacterial infection.

Diagnostic tests that evaluate for a type IV hypersensitivity reaction include tuberculin skin test, Candida extract test, and patch test.
Image Description:

Type IV hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by antigen-specific T cells, unlike all other hypersensitivity reactions, which are antibody-mediated. T helper cells (CD4+ cells; Th cells) mainly act by cytokine-mediated recruitment of inflammatory cells to the site of the target cells.

T-cell receptors (TCR) present on sensitized CD4+ cells recognize and bind to specific exogenous antigens (e.g., bacteria, viruses). These antigens are bound to the major histocompatibility complex class II (MHC II), a transmembrane protein present on the surface of antigen-presenting cells, like macrophages. Th cells are divided into two subsets based on the cytokines they produce:
- Bacterial and viral infections predominantly activate Th1 cells, which release cytokines that preferentially recruit neutrophils and macrophages (e.g., IFNγ, TNFα). Activated macrophages release reactive oxygen species (ROS) and nitric oxide (NO), which aid in the destruction of phagocytosed pathogens.
- Helminthic or parasitic infections predominantly activate Th2 cells, which release cytokines that preferentially recruit eosinophils (e.g., IL5). Activated eosinophils release major basic protein (MBP), which aids in the destruction of helminths and signals mast cells to release histamine.

Cytokines, ROS, and MBP recruit more inflammatory cells to the site of the reaction and amplify the inflammatory response, which typically becomes evident ∼ 48 hours after antigen-exposure (i.e., delayed hypersensitivity).

C) INCORRECT:

Antibody-mediated cytotoxicity is characteristic of type II hypersensitivity reactions. A type II hypersensitivity reaction manifesting with fever, hemoptysis, and cough would be seen in Goodpasture syndrome. However, the histological findings in Goodpasture syndrome would show linear IgG depositions, not caseating granuloma formation. In addition, granuloma formation in patients with tuberculosis is not associated with a type II hypersensitivity reaction.

D) INCORRECT:

A combined type III hypersensitivity/type IV hypersensitivity reaction manifesting with fever, cough, and weight loss would be seen in hypersensitivity pneumonitis (e.g., farmer's lung). Exposure to specific disease-precipitating antigens (e.g., fungal spores and thermophilic actinomycetes) induces a combined type III/IV hypersensitivity reaction that manifests with IgG antibody-antigen complex deposition in the lung and subsequent granulomatous inflammation. However, a chest x-ray would typically show patchy or diffuse reticulonodular infiltrates, and histological examination would show noncaseating granuloma rather than caseating granuloma formation. In addition, granuloma formation in patients with tuberculosis is not associated with a combined type III/IV hypersensitivity reaction.

E) INCORRECT:

Immune complex deposition is characteristic of type III hypersensitivity reactions. A type III hypersensitivity reaction manifesting with granulomas, fever, weight loss, and hemoptysis would be seen in pneumonitis secondary to systemic lupus erythematosus. However, SLE would manifest with noncaseating granulomas rather than caseating granulomas. In addition, granuloma formation in patients with tuberculosis is not associated with a type III hypersensitivity reaction.
questions.hint: This patients symptoms and histology findings are characteristic of pulmonary tuberculosis (TB).

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 2-week history of worsening intermittent headaches, double vision, nausea, fatigue, and a low-grade fever. He has not been able to go to work since then. His wife says that he “was acting weird” last night. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 2 years ago. His current medications include lamivudine, abacavir, and efavirenz. His wife reports that he has a stressful job and sometimes forgets to take his medications. He appears lethargic. He is oriented to time and person but not to place. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 121/77 mm Hg. There is nuchal rigidity. On neurologic examination, there is an abduction deficit of both eyes. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 4,000/mm3, CD4+ lymphocyte count is 95/mm3, and platelet count is 300,000/mm3. Cranial CT scan shows basilar meningeal thickening; there is no evidence of increased intracranial pressure. A lumbar puncture is performed. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows:


Leukocyte count
120/mm3



Segmented neutrophils
30%


Lymphocytes
70%


Glucose
10 mg/dL


Opening pressure
200 mm H2O


Protein
112 mg/dL


Adenosine deaminase
increased


Results of blood and cerebrospinal fluid cultures are pending. Which of the following is the most likely infectious agent?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae is the single most common cause of bacterial meningitis among adults in the US. However, meningitis caused by S. pneumoniae usually has a more sudden onset, and CSF analysis typically reveals elevated cell count (> 1000/mm3) with neutrophil predominance, rather than lymphocyte predominance. Moreover, this patient should have received the pneumococcal vaccination, which is recommended for all adults ≥ 50 years of age and individuals < 50 years of age with risk factors for invasive pneumococcal disease (e.g., immunosuppression).

B) INCORRECT:

Listeria monocytogenes is the most common cause of bacterial meningitis in immunocompromised individuals and often manifests with focal neurological deficits, such as cranial nerve palsies. However, meningitis caused by L. monocytogenes usually has a more sudden onset, and CSF analysis typically reveals elevated cell count (> 1000/mm3) with neutrophil predominance, rather than lymphocyte predominance.

C) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) can cause meningitis, especially in immunocompromised individuals. CSF findings in viral meningitis typically include a leukocyte count of 10–500/mm3 with lymphocyte predominance, similar to this patient's findings. However, viral meningitis usually has a more abrupt onset and the CSF glucose concentration is normal or only slightly decreased. More commonly, HSV causes herpes encephalitis, which typically manifests with a prodrome of headaches and fever, followed by sudden focal neurological deficits, seizures, and altered mental status.

D) INCORRECT:

Toxoplasma gondii can cause cerebral toxoplasmosis, which typically affects patients with HIV/AIDS with a CD4 count < 100/mm3. Cerebral toxoplasmosis can manifest with fever, headache, altered mental status, and focal neurological deficits. However, CT typically shows multiple ring-enhancing lesions (brain abscesses) rather than the basilar meningeal thickening seen here.

E) CORRECT:

Mycobacterium tuberculosis can cause tuberculous meningitis in immunocompromised adults, most commonly due to reactivation of latent tuberculosis (TB). Patients with HIV infection and a CD4 count < 400/mm3 are at increased risk of developing reactivation TB; the risk of CNS involvement is increased in patients with a CD4 count < 100/mm3, as seen here. CSF findings typically include moderately elevated opening pressure, cell count between 30–300/mm3 with lymphocyte predominance, elevated protein concentration, and decreased glucose concentration. The presence of acid-fast bacilli on CSF and/or a CSF culture positive for M. tuberculosis confirms the diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Coxsackievirus is a common cause of viral meningitis. CSF findings in viral meningitis typically include a leukocyte count of 10–500/mm3 with lymphocyte predominance, similar to this patient's findings. However, viral meningitis usually has a more abrupt onset, and the CSF glucose concentration is normal or only slightly decreased. Focal neurological deficits, such as cranial nerve palsies, would not be expected.
questions.hint: This patient's 2-week history of low-grade fever and headaches in combination with altered mental status and nuchal rigidity on physical examination raises concern for subacute meningitis. The presence of a cranial nerve palsy (abducens nerve palsy), bibasilar meningeal thickening on cranial CT scan, and increased adenosine deaminase (ADA) on cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis suggest a particular causal organism.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of intermittent low-grade fever and a worsening productive cough. During this time, he also has had a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss despite no change in his appetite. He has been unable to climb more than 2 flights of stairs because of shortness of breath. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and gastroesophageal reflux disease. His medications are metformin and omeprazole. He does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. He works as a nurse and has been a Peace Corps medical officer in Bolivia until 2 months ago. He appears ill. He is 176 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 61 kg (134 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. Lung auscultation discloses diffuse crackles over the left lung. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.8 g/dL and leukocyte count is 12,000/mm3. Chest x-ray shows a consolidation in the left lower lobe with ipsilateral hilar enlargement. Microscopic examination of the sputum shows acid-fast bacilli. Sputum cultures are pending. After placing the patient in an airborne infection isolation room, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Isoniazid, rifampin, streptomycin, and ethambutol for 6 months
Await culture results before initiating treatment
Isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol for 2 months, followed by isoniazid and rifampin for 4 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the chest can be used in patients with TB to rule out differential diagnoses or to detect subtle parenchymal changes, but a chest x-ray is the recommended modality for the diagnosis of active TB. This patient's x-ray findings of consolidation in the left lower lobe with ipsilateral hilar enlargement are consistent with primary, active, pulmonary TB. Therefore, a CT scan is not indicated at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Isoniazid, rifampin, and ethambutol are antibiotic agents commonly used in the treatment of TB. Streptomycin was formerly used to treat TB but is no longer considered a first-line therapy option because of widespread resistance. Currently, aminoglycosides serve as second-line agents and are only used when primary agents are contraindicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Based on this patient's clinical, radiological, and laboratory findings, treatment for suspected active TB should be initiated without delay. Since culturing TB can take up to 6 weeks, it is not useful to wait for the results before beginning therapy. Nonetheless, cultures should still be requested so that treatment can be adjusted according to the bacteria's drug susceptibility, which is shown in the culture results.

D) INCORRECT:

Tuberculin skin testing (TST) is usually indicated to detect latent TB and can determine whether a person has ever been infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis. This patient, however, shows findings consistent with active TB, meaning that they are currently infected with M. tuberculosis. Therefore, TST would not add any diagnostic value.

E) CORRECT:

Rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol (RIPE regimen) are a standard antibiotic therapy for active TB. Treatment consists of a 2-month intensive phase with all four antibiotics simultaneously (to increase serum concentration, optimize eradication of the bacteria, and minimize the risk of developing antibiotic resistance), followed by a continuation phase with only isoniazid and rifampin for at least 4 months (to reduce the risk of relapse). Patients receiving antituberculous drugs should be regularly monitored for adverse effects (e.g., hepatotoxicity, optic neuritis). Sputum samples should be sent monthly for microscopy and culture until two consecutive cultures are negative.

F) INCORRECT:

Isoniazid and rifapentine therapy for 3 months is a first-line treatment option for patients with latent TB, who are at risk of infection reactivation. This patient shows signs and symptoms of active TB; therefore, therapy with isoniazid and rifapentine is not sufficient.

G) INCORRECT:

Interferon-γ release assay is used to test for latent TB. Since this patient has findings that strongly suggest active TB, an interferon-γ release assay would most likely be positive but would not provide any additional information or influence the management of the infection.
questions.hint: A 2-month history of productive cough and systemic symptoms (low-grade fever, fatigue, dyspnea, weight loss) in this patient who worked in a region endemic for tuberculosis (TB) raises suspicion for TB infection. The consolidation in the lower lobe and hilar lymphadenopathy on chest x-ray and acid-fast bacilli on sputum microscopy support the diagnosis of primary active TB.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man who is a prisoner comes to the county jail urgent care clinic because of a 1-month history of productive cough, malaise, and right-sided chest pain. During this time, he also has had shortness of breath and a 6-kg (13-Ib) weight loss. Three weeks ago, he was treated with amoxicillin for pneumonia but his symptoms did not improve. He worked as a construction worker for 15 years. He has HIV infection and hypertension. Medications include lisinopril and antiretroviral therapy. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F) and blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. On pulmonary examination, scattered crackles are heard bilaterally; there is dullness to percussion at the right lung base. Chest x-ray shows right-sided hilar lymphadenopathy, a fibrous, cavitary lesion in the right lower lobe, and right-sided pleural effusion. CD4 count is 600 cells/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) can manifest with B symptoms as well as hilar lymphadenopathy and pleural effusion on chest x-ray, all of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, mediastinal masses, which cause chest pain, shortness of breath, and cough, are a common feature of HL. However, this patient's chest x-ray shows no signs of a mediastinal mass; his cavitary lesion is not consistent with HL. Moreover, patients with HL typically have a dry rather than productive cough and often present with painless lymphadenopathy, especially in the cervical nodes, which is not seen here.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (a: PA view; b: left lateral view) and CT chest (c: with contrast; coronal plane) of a patient with nodular sclerosing Hodgkin lymphoma

The PA radiograph shows an abnormal superior mediastinum that is dense, markedly widened, and lobulated (green overlay). On the lateral radiograph, there is opacification of the retrosternal space, which should normally be a clear area. CT confirms the presence of a large anterior locally invasive mediastinal soft tissue mass (arrows).

Li: liver; LV: left ventricle

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary sarcoidosis can manifest with coughing, dyspnea, chest pain, and constitutional symptoms. However, pulmonary sarcoidosis usually manifests with a dry rather than productive cough, and a chest x-ray would show bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and reticular or ground-glass opacities, not a unilateral cavitary lesion.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view)

The lungs have a pattern of innumerable small nodular opacities. The hila are enlarged and lobulated (red overlay) and the right paratracheal stripe is widened (green overlay).

Bilateral hilar and right mediastinal adenopathy is suggestive of sarcoidosis and is referred to as the “Garland triad” or “1-2-3 sign.”

C) INCORRECT:

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) can manifest subacutely with dyspnea, constitutional symptoms, bilateral crackles on chest auscultation, and pleural effusion, all of which are seen here. In addition, PCP occurs almost exclusively in immunocompromised individuals, such as patients with HIV infection. However, chest x-ray in PCP typically shows symmetrical, diffuse interstitial infiltrates extending from the perihilar region, not a unilateral cavitary lesion. Finally, PCP typically occurs at a CD4 count of < 200/mm3.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with pneumocystis pneumonia

Parenchymal opacification is seen in a predominantly perihilar distribution (green overlay)

Pneumocystis pneumonia frequently demonstrates as bilateral perihilar opacification with a fine reticular appearance that progresses to air-space consolidation. On CT, it may appear with a ground-glass appearance. Cystic lesions may also be seen. Atypical findings on imaging include nodules, lymphadenopathy, and effusions.

H: heart; SB: stomach bubble

D) CORRECT:

A productive cough, constitutional symptoms, and chest x-ray findings suggestive of a Ghon complex (hilar lymphadenopathy and a pulmonary lesion) in a patient living in crowded conditions (prison) are strongly suggestive of pulmonary tuberculosis (TB). The lack of improvement of this patient's respiratory symptoms with antibiotic therapy should further raise suspicion for this condition. Pulmonary TB is often accompanied by tuberculous pleurisy, which manifests with chest pain and pleural effusion, as seen in this patient. The patient's chest x-ray findings are consistent with primary tuberculosis, which commonly affects the middle and lower pulmonary lobes. In contrast to primary TB, reactivation TB most commonly affects the upper pulmonary lobes and manifests with multiple cavitary lesions with calcifications and consolidations.

In patients with HIV, reactivated pulmonary TB can also manifest in the lower lobes. The analysis of sputum specimens via culture, microscopy, and/or PCR is the easiest and least invasive way to confirm suspected active pulmonary TB.
Image Description:

Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

E) INCORRECT:

Pleural mesothelioma (the most common type of mesothelioma) can manifest with dyspnea, chest pain, constitutional symptoms, and pleural effusion, all of which are seen in this patient. In addition, mesothelioma develops secondary to asbestos exposure, which this patient might have had while working on construction sites. However, chest x-ray in mesothelioma typically shows multiple nodular pleural lesions seen as pleural thickening, not a unilateral cavitary lesion.
Image Description:

CT chest (with contrast; coronal plane) of a patient with malignant mesothelioma

Nodular pleural thickening (hatched green overlay) encases the left lung and the volume of the left hemithorax (red dashed line) is reduced compared to the right (green dashed line). Enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes are present (red overlay).

The findings are compatible with malignant mesothelioma, although confluent pleural metastatic disease can have a similar appearance. Both primary and secondary pleural malignancies can cause pleural nodules, diffuse pleural thickening, and pleural effusion.

AO: aorta; LV: left ventricle; PA: pulmonary artery
questions.hint: Analysis of the pleural fluid would show lymphocyte-predominant leukocytosis and high levels of protein, lactate dehydrogenase, and adenosine deaminase.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because she is worried that her child may have tuberculosis. One week ago, the patient returned from a trip to Moldova, where he visited his grandparents. The grandfather has had a cough during the past weeks and received the diagnosis of active tuberculosis (TB) 2 days ago. The child feels well. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. Physical examination and chest x-ray show no abnormalities. A tuberculin skin test (TST) shows an induration of 3 mm in diameter after 2 days. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Repeat tuberculin skin test in 1 week
No further management is indicated at this time
Initiate rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A repeat TST is recommended in children who have been exposed to TB, even if the original TST or interferon-gamma release assay is negative. However, the repeat test should be performed 8–10 weeks after the child was last exposed to TB, and this patient was last exposed only 1 week ago.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has a negative TST and is currently asymptomatic. However, he has been in close contact with an individual with active TB and, due to his age, is at high risk for progression from LTBI to active TB. Therefore, a different approach is indicated at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

The interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA) is a blood test used to diagnose latent or active TB. This test is more specific than TST and may be used to confirm a positive TST result or rule out a false-negative TST if the likelihood of infection is high. However, IGRA test results may be indeterminate in children < 5 years of age. Moreover, children of this age who have had significant exposure to active TB are indicated for management regardless of initial test results and IGRA testing is, therefore, not necessary at this point.

D) CORRECT:

A 4-month course of rifampin monotherapy is one regimen for the treatment of latent TB infection (LTBI). Children < 5 years of age have an underdeveloped immune system, which increases the likelihood of false-negative TST results, a rapid progression from LTBI to active TB, and a severe disease course. Window prophylaxis should therefore be offered to all children of this age with significant exposure to TB in the past 8 weeks, regardless of the initial examination findings and/or test results. A follow-up TST should be performed 8–10 weeks after the child was last exposed to TB. If the follow-up TST is negative and there is no suspicion of a false-negative result, the treatment may be discontinued. HIV-positive individuals should be managed similarly but receive full-length prophylaxis, even if the follow-up TST is negative. Isolation measures apply only to those with suspected or confirmed active TB.

Recently, nitrosamine impurities in rifampin and rifapentine have been detected. Because the risk of not using these medications for the treatment of TB is considered higher than the possible risk from nitrosamine ingestion, the US Food and Drug Administration currently allows certain manufacturers to distribute rifampin and rifapentine with a certain amount of nitrosamine compounds. Alternative treatment regimens to rifampin are 3 months of isoniazid and rifapentine, 3 months of isoniazid and rifampin, or 9 months of isoniazid monotherapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol is the most common antibiotic regimen for the treatment of active TB. This patient has no symptoms of active TB (e.g., cough, fever) and his TST is negative. This patient may have LTBI, which is managed differently.
questions.hint: This child has had significant exposure to an individual with active tuberculosis (TB). Although his tuberculin skin test (TST) is currently negative (induration of < 5 mm), this boy may already have latent TB infection (LTBI). Children < 5 years of age are at high risk for progression from LTBI to active TB and should be managed accordingly.

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Repeat tuberculin skin test in 2 weeks
Initiate rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A repeat TST may be indicated if test results are indeterminate, which can occur in individuals with HIV. The TST should also be repeated in all individuals with an initially negative TST within 10 weeks of exposure to active tuberculosis. This patient has a positive TST and no known exposure to active tuberculosis, therefore, a different step in management is more appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Sputum samples are the most commonly used samples to confirm the presence of tuberculosis bacilli in patients with clinical features suggestive of active tuberculosis. This patient has no clinical features of active tuberculosis and no abnormal findings on chest x-ray, which rules out active tuberculosis. LTBI requires a different step in management.

C) INCORRECT:

A positive TST combined with a normal chest x-ray suggests LTBI, which requires further management.

D) CORRECT:

All individuals with HIV should be screened for LTBI, regardless of the presence of additional risk factors for tuberculosis, as there is a high likelihood of progression to active tuberculosis. A positive screening test (i.e., interferon-γ release assay or TST) in an asymptomatic individual, combined with a normal chest x-ray, indicates LTBI. Depending on patient characteristics, an induration of ≥ 5 mm, ≥ 10 mm, or ≥ 15 mm can indicate a positive TST (see the “Positive TST according to induration diameter” table). In individuals with HIV, TST sensitivity may be reduced due to anergy, and therefore the induration cutoff is lowered to 5 mm to minimize false-negative results. For individuals with HIV, a long regimen (i.e., ≥ 6 months) of isoniazid and pyridoxine is the most appropriate treatment for LTBI.

Individuals with newly diagnosed HIV should also be screened for associated complications (e.g., AIDS-defining illnesses) and coinfections such as hepatitis B and C, STIs (syphilis, gonorrhea, chlamydia, and, for women, trichomonas), and toxoplasmosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol (RIPE TB regimen) is the appropriate regimen for active tuberculosis. This patient has no clinical features of active tuberculosis and no abnormal findings on chest x-ray, which rules out active tuberculosis. LTBI requires a different step in management.
questions.hint: For individuals with HIV, a TST is considered positive if there is an induration of ≥ 5 mm after 48–72 hours. A positive TST combined with a normal chest x-ray indicates latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI).

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man is hospitalized with a one-month history of progressive shortness of breath, right-sided chest discomfort, fevers, and a 4.5-kg weight loss. He has a history of alcohol use disorder and is currently homeless. He takes no medications.
On examination, his temperature is 38°C, and his oxygen saturation is 92% while he is breathing ambient air. He has diminished breath sounds on the right, with dullness to percussion halfway up the right lung field. His cardiac examination is normal, and he has no lymphadenopathy or lower-extremity edema.
His hemoglobin level and leukocyte count are within normal limits. His serum lactate dehydrogenase level is 149 U/liter (reference range, 100–190), and his total protein level is 7.0 g/dL (5.5–8.0).
A tuberculin skin test is positive. A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
Pleural fluid analysis reveals a lactate dehydrogenase level of 186 U/liter and a protein level of 4.9 g/dL. Cell count is notable for an erythrocyte count of 1682 per microliter and a nucleated cell count of 4510 per microliter with 71% lymphocytes, 12% macrophages, and 17% neutrophils. Gram stain, bacterial cultures, and cytologic findings are negative.
Which one of the following next steps is most likely to yield a diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with tuberculous pleural effusions may have concurrent parenchymal disease, but this is not always the case. For this reason, sputum acid-fast bacilli smears are often unrevealing and have a low diagnostic yield for pleural disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Pleural fluid amylase levels can be elevated in malignancy or esophageal rupture but would not be helpful in diagnosing a tuberculous effusion.

C) CORRECT:

Tuberculous effusions are one of the most common forms of extrapulmonary tuberculosis (TB). The effusions are exudative in nature and typically lymphocytic. In older patients, pleural tuberculous effusions are most commonly from reactivation of TB; in children, effusions are more commonly seen in primary TB.

Pleural biopsy is often necessary to diagnose a tuberculous pleural effusion because cultures and acid-fast bacilli smears are often negative. Although an elevated pleural adenosine deaminase (ADA) level is highly suggestive of tuberculous pleural effusion, in most settings, the turnaround time of the laboratory result can be limiting. An ADA level <40 U/liter generally rules out tuberculous effusion. Some studies suggest that a presumptive diagnosis of pleural TB can be made in patients whose pleural fluid consists of >75% lymphocytes if the ADA level is >40 U/liter. This patient’s pleural fluid contains 71% lymphocytes, which precludes using the ADA level in this fashion.

Key learning point: The best test to diagnose pleural tuberculosis is pleural biopsy with acid-fast staining and culture.

D) INCORRECT:

Pleural fluid cytology is used to help diagnose a malignant effusion; it is not useful in diagnosing pleural tuberculous disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Interferon-gamma release assays are useful in diagnosing latent TB but not active disease. A positive assay would not change the management in a patient with a positive tuberculin skin test.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man reports a 2-week history of cough, night sweats, and fevers. He denies shortness of breath or chest pain. His cough produces yellow phlegm streaked with small amounts of blood.
His medical history includes rheumatoid arthritis, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes. His medications include lisinopril, metformin, and adalimumab. He does not smoke and has not traveled recently.
He is afebrile with a blood pressure of 110/79 mm Hg, a heart rate of 98 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. He has no adenopathy. He has a few crackles in the left mid-lung field. His cardiac examination is unremarkable. He has no lower-extremity edema and no rashes.
A complete blood count shows a leukocyte count of 11,200 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000) with 66% neutrophils (40–70), 21% lymphocytes (22–44), and 13% monocytes (4–11).
An x-ray of the chest is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following studies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Induced sputum acid-fast bacilli stain and culture
Placement of a tuberculin skin test

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sputum cytology is used in the evaluation of some lung cancers, but this patient's clinical picture is more acute than is typical for lung cancer. Furthermore, TNF inhibitors do not increase the risk of lung cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Urine Histoplasma antigen testing can be helpful if pulmonary histoplasmosis is suspected, but this disease does not commonly cause cavitary lung lesions.

C) CORRECT:

Tumor necrosis factor (TNF) is an important factor in the body’s defense against Mycobacterium tuberculosis. TNF inhibitors increase the risk for reactivation tuberculosis. Current guidelines recommend screening for latent tuberculosis in all patients who are to be started on TNF inhibitors.

Patients who have symptoms consistent with active tuberculosis (e.g., fever, night sweats, hemoptysis) or who develop a cavitary opacity on chest radiograph (as is seen on this patient’s film in the midzone of the left lung) should have their sputum tested for acid-fast bacilli. Induced sputum testing is preferred over bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage because it is less invasive and confers a lower risk of exposure to providers and health care staff.

Key learning point: Patients treated with a tumor necrosis factor inhibitor are at increased risk for reactivation of latent tuberculosis.

D) INCORRECT:

A tuberculin skin test is used to assess for latent tuberculosis, but it is not an appropriate study to look for reactivation disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients who have symptoms consistent with active tuberculosis (e.g., fever, night sweats, hemoptysis) or who develop a cavitary opacity on chest radiograph (as is seen on this patient’s film in the midzone of the left lung) should have their sputum tested for acid-fast bacilli. Induced sputum testing is preferred over bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage because it is less invasive and confers a lower risk of exposure to providers and health care staff.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman who moved to the United States from the Philippines one month ago undergoes a tuberculin skin test that results in 12 mm of induration at 48 hours. She states that she has not experienced any fevers, chills, weight loss, night sweats, or cough. She has no known contacts with active tuberculosis, and she has never received the bacille Calmette-Guérin vaccine.
A chest radiograph reveals no evidence of lymphadenopathy or obvious parenchymal abnormality. An HIV test is negative.
Which one of the following management approaches is warranted in this patient?

choices.text: Repeat the chest radiograph in 6 months
Begin treatment with isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

According to current U.S. guidelines, the interferon-gamma release assay may be used as an alternative to the TST in recent immigrants, particularly those who have received the bacille Calmette-Guérin vaccine. However, the interferon-gamma release assay test is unnecessary in a patient who has already had a positive TST.

B) INCORRECT:

Merely repeating chest imaging in 6 months is inappropriate in a patient who is likely to have latent tuberculosis, given the risk for progression to active disease if untreated.

C) INCORRECT:

Bronchoscopy findings are not likely to alter management in an asymptomatic patient with a normal chest radiograph who can generate adequate sputum samples.

D) INCORRECT:

Treatment for active tuberculosis with a four-drug regimen is unwarranted in an asymptomatic patient with unremarkable chest imaging.

E) CORRECT:

A positive tuberculin skin test (TST) in a recent immigrant from a region with endemic Mycobacterium tuberculosis merits treatment for latent tuberculosis, using one of the five recommended treatment regimens (see “Drug regimens for treatment of LTBI” table):

Preferred regimens:

• 4 months of daily rifampin
• 3 months of weekly isoniazid plus rifapentine
• 3 months of daily isoniazid plus rifampin

Alternative regimens:

• 6 months of daily isoniazid
• 9 months of daily isoniazid

Key learning point: When an asymptomatic patient who recently emigrated from a tuberculosis-endemic country is found to have a positive tuberculin skin test and a normal chest radiograph, the most appropriate next step is treatment for latent tuberculosis.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man arrives at the emergency department reporting a 3-week history of cough, fatigue, night sweats, and intermittent fevers. He reports no prior medical problems. He is from Mexico, has no health insurance, and lives in a boarding house with several other men. He reports no sick contacts.
His temperature is 38.3°C, and his lungs are clear on auscultation. He has a leukocyte count of 8000 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000), a serum creatinine level of 1.6 mg/dL (0.8–1.3), and a random glucose level of 180 mg/dL (< 140). An initial chest radiograph reveals a small nodular infiltrate in the apical portion of the right upper lobe and a calcified hilar lymph node.
Which one of the following diagnostic approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Obtain a urine sample for acid-fast bacilli culture
Obtain three sputum samples for acid-fast bacilli smear microscopy and culture
Obtain a bronchoalveolar lavage for acid-fast bacilli smear microscopy and culture and fungal testing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urine AFB culture is appropriate if genitourinary TB is suspected, but it is not indicated when evaluating a patient for pulmonary TB.

B) INCORRECT:

Although an interferon-gamma release assay or tuberculin skin test would be helpful in this patient, it is important to recognize that a negative test result does not rule out active TB.

C) CORRECT:

Reactivated pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) should be suspected in patients from high-prevalence areas who present with symptoms consistent with this diagnosis, such as cough, fatigue, night sweats, and fever. A chest radiograph can be suggestive of the diagnosis if it shows evidence of healed TB infection and focal infiltration of one or both upper lobes.

The recommended approach to diagnosing active pulmonary TB is to first obtain sputum acid-fast bacilli (AFB) smear microscopy and culture. In addition, in patients with pulmonary TB, sputum AFB cultures are important to determine the drug susceptibility of the infecting organism.

Key learning point: The approach to diagnosing active pulmonary tuberculosis should include evaluation of at least three sputum samples for acid-fast bacilli smear microscopy and culture.

D) INCORRECT:

Although bronchoalveolar lavage may be helpful in diagnosing pulmonary TB or other causes of pneumonia, sputum AFB smears should be performed first; if sputum AFB testing is positive, the patient can be spared invasive testing.

E) INCORRECT:

Although an interferon-gamma release assay or tuberculin skin test would be helpful in this patient, it is important to recognize that a negative test result does not rule out active TB.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man who immigrated to the United States from Ethiopia 3 years ago presents for routine care. He has no physical concerns and no significant medical history.
A recent screening test for HIV antibody was negative. A tuberculin skin test, placed 48 hours ago, now has 12 mm of induration. The patient received vaccination with bacille Calmette-Guérin at birth.
What is the best next step for this patient?

choices.text: Interferon-gamma release assay and repeat tuberculin skin test
Induced-sputum smear exams for acid-fast bacilli

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If the patient is asymptomatic, a chest radiograph is appropriate to rule out active TB before therapy for latent TB is initiated. Treatment for latent tuberculosis should not be started without first ruling out active TB.

B) INCORRECT:

An interferon-gamma release assay can be used in place of a TST and is particularly useful in the setting of recent bacille Calmette-Guérin immunization. However, an interferon-gamma release assay is not necessary if a TST is already positive; there is also some suggestion that a recent TST may increase the results of subsequent IGRAs, although the significance of this is unclear. A repeat TST is not necessary in a patient who already has a positive TST.

C) CORRECT:

The criteria for tuberculin skin test (TST) positivity depend on underlying risk factors.

• An induration of ≥ 5 mm is considered a positive result for people with HIV, people who are close contacts of an individual with tuberculosis (TB), people who have a chest radiograph suggestive of prior TB, and people who are otherwise immunosuppressed.
• An induration of ≥ 10 mm is considered a positive result for people who have immigrated within the past 5 years from a TB-endemic area, as well as for health care workers, people who inject drugs, homeless people, residents and staff of long-term care facilities, children < 4 years of age, and people with recent TST conversion (i.e., an increase of ≥ 10 mm within 2 years).
• An induration of ≥ 15 mm is considered a positive result for everyone else.

Report or documentation of prior vaccination with bacille Calmette-Guérin should be ignored when interpreting TST results. If a patient has symptoms of active TB, diagnostic studies, including sputum acid-fast bacilli smears and cultures, should be undertaken. If the patient is asymptomatic (as in this case), a chest radiograph is appropriate to rule out active TB before therapy for latent TB is initiated. An interferon-gamma release assay can be used in place of a TST and is particularly useful in the setting of recent bacille Calmette-Guérin immunization. However, an interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA) is not necessary if a TST is already positive; there is also some suggestion that a recent TST may increase the results of subsequent IGRAs, although the significance of this is unclear.

Key learning point: The minimum diameter of induration on a tuberculin skin test that indicates tuberculosis infection in an immigrant from a tuberculosis-endemic area is 10 mm.

D) INCORRECT:

A repeat TST is not necessary in a patient who already has a positive TST.

E) INCORRECT:

If a patient has symptoms of active TB, diagnostic studies, including sputum acid-fast bacilli smears and cultures, should be undertaken. However, if the patient is asymptomatic, a chest radiograph is appropriate to rule out active TB before therapy for latent TB is initiated, as opposed to induced-sputum smear exams for acid-fast bacilli which are indicated for symptomatic patients.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman presents with 2 months of dry cough, increasing dyspnea, drenching night sweats, difficulty lying supine, and 4.5 kg of unintentional weight loss. She has no hemoptysis. She emigrated from Mexico to the United States 2 years ago and currently attends a local college where her screening tuberculin skin test was negative at admission. She recently returned from a trip to Mexico.
Chest radiograph demonstrates a large right pleural effusion and hilar lymphadenopathy.
Thoracentesis reveals straw-colored fluid, with 5000 white cells per mm3 (90% lymphocytes). The pleural fluid has a pH of 7.2, a protein level of 3.3 g/dL, and a glucose level of 55 mg/dL. A repeat tuberculin skin test is negative, and an HIV test is negative.
Which one of the following is most likely to identify the cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Order CT scan of the chest
Obtain a pleural fluid interferon-gamma release assay
Obtain a sputum culture for Mycobacterium tuberculosis
Stain the pleural fluid for acid-fast bacillus
Arrange for pleural biopsy with mycobacterial culture

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chest CT can be helpful if other features of TB are present, but this scenario is more common in older patients with chronic TB and effusions.

B) INCORRECT:

Although studies on pleural fluid, such as measurement of the adenosine deaminase level or an interferon-gamma release assay, may be helpful, different studies report varying sensitivities and specificities for these tests; the definitive test for pleural TB remains the pleural biopsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Although sputum acid-fast bacilli staining and culture may reveal the diagnosis, in this case, the patient is not producing sputum, and a pleural biopsy has a higher yield.

D) INCORRECT:

In primary TB pleuritis, acid-fast stains of the pleural fluid sediment are rarely positive, but in reactivation TB, they can be positive 50% of the time. Mycobacterial culture of the pleural fluid is positive 25% to 30% of the time when the pleurisy is in the setting of primary TB and 60% of the time when the pleurisy is due to reactivation.

E) CORRECT:

Pleural tuberculosis (TB) with an effusion may develop within weeks to months of initial infection (primary TB pleuritis) or in the setting of reactivation TB. Primary TB pleuritis is most often seen in children, whereas reactivation TB pleuritis is more common in adults. The pleural effusions are usually small to moderate in size but can be massive. They are typically unilateral but may be bilateral. The best diagnostic approach is to obtain a pleural biopsy. This biopsy specimen often shows granulomas; mycobacterial culture of a needle biopsy specimen may be positive even when granulomas are not seen on histologic examination.

Although sputum acid-fast bacilli staining and culture may reveal the diagnosis, in this case, the patient is not producing sputum, and a pleural biopsy has a higher yield.

The tuberculin skin test may initially be negative in the setting of TB pleuritis.

Key learning point: The best test to diagnose pleural tuberculosis is pleural biopsy with mycobacterial culture.

questions.text:
An 85-year-old woman who resides in a nursing home presents with a 4-week history of cough, fevers, and night sweats. Her expectorate has been blood-tinged for the past week, and she has lost 7 kg in the past 2 months. She appears thin and has right-sided post-tussive rales.
A chest radiograph shows a thick-walled cavity in the right-upper lobe.
Which one of the following next steps is best to establish the diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: CT-guided biopsy of the cavitary lesion
Sputum stain and culture for acid-fast bacilli

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bronchoscopy and transbronchial biopsy should be reserved for patients who are unable to expectorate sputum or those with nondiagnostic results and lesions amenable to transbronchial biopsy.

B) INCORRECT:

CT-guided biopsy of the cavitary lesion should be performed if less-invasive testing is nondiagnostic.

C) INCORRECT:

Neither the tuberculin skin test nor the serum interferon-gamma release assay can distinguish between active and latent infection. In addition, these tests may be falsely negative, especially in patients who are older, anergic, or immunocompromised.

D) CORRECT:

The initial approach to diagnosing active pulmonary tuberculosis is sputum stain and culture for acid-fast bacilli, which can be done relatively easily and quickly. Patients with cavitary disease are often smear-positive because they generally have a higher burden of disease. In addition to stain and culture for acid-fast bacilli, nucleic-acid testing may be helpful in establishing the diagnosis of tuberculosis, although culture of the organism is still required to fully assess its drug susceptibility.

Key learning point: The best test to confirm a clinical diagnosis of active pulmonary tuberculosis is sputum stain and culture for acid-fast bacilli.

E) INCORRECT:

Neither the tuberculin skin test nor the serum interferon-gamma release assay can distinguish between active and latent infection. In addition, these tests may be falsely negative, especially in patients who are older, anergic, or immunocompromised.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man from Mexico with a history of type 2 diabetes presents for follow-up of persistent progressive dysuria, pelvic pain, and occasional night sweats.
On initial examination, he was noted to have an enlarged and tender prostate, with positive leukocyte esterase on urinalysis. He received empiric treatment for prostatitis with 4 weeks of oral ciprofloxacin. His urine culture was ultimately negative.
He states that his symptoms initially improved after treatment but then returned 2 weeks ago. He has also developed increasing fevers and difficulty voiding.
His urinalysis shows 2+ leukocyte esterase, 1+ protein, >100 white cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2), and 20 red cells per high-power field (0–2). No organisms are seen on high-power field. Urine culture is negative. Nucleic acid amplification testing for Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae is negative.
Which one of the following next steps is best in this patient's evaluation?

choices.text: Send urine for BK virus polymerase chain-reaction testing
Send urine for acid-fast bacilli smear and cultures
Send urine for bacterial culture after prostatic massage

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sending urine for BK virus polymerase chain-reaction testing is not warranted. Although BK virus can cause hemorrhagic cystitis in kidney transplant patients and other immunocompromised hosts, it would not be expected to cause this presentation in an immunocompetent host.

B) INCORRECT:

Urine cytology and cystoscopy evaluation should be considered in cases of isolated hematuria but not necessarily in cases associated with sterile pyuria.

C) CORRECT:

The genitourinary tract is a common site of extrapulmonary tuberculosis. Tuberculous epididymitis or orchitis manifests with pain and swelling. Tuberculous urethritis can cause urinary obstruction due to stricture formation. The findings of sterile pyuria, hematuria, and proteinuria, or symptoms of chronic prostatitis not resolving with standard antibiotics, should prompt investigation for tuberculosis, particularly if the patient is from an endemic or high-prevalence area.

Evaluation of at least three early-morning urine samples for acid-fast bacilli smear and culture are recommended. Urine nucleic acid amplification testing for tuberculosis, when available, is more sensitive and specific than acid-fast bacilli culture and smear.

Key learning point: The findings of sterile pyuria and chronic genitourinary symptoms in a man from a tuberculosis-endemic area should prompt examination for tuberculosis by sending urine for acid-fast bacillus smear and cultures.

D) INCORRECT:

Urine cytology and cystoscopy evaluation should be considered in cases of isolated hematuria but not necessarily in cases associated with sterile pyuria.

E) INCORRECT:

Repeat urine culture after prostatic massage is useful to diagnose bacterial prostatitis, but after failure of an appropriate antibiotic course, evaluation for tuberculosis is warranted. Chlamydia trachomatis can cause urethritis, epididymitis, and proctitis in men, as well as sterile pyuria. However, this patient’s presentation makes this diagnosis less likely, and his testing for chlamydia was negative.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old man has a 15-mm area of induration 48 hours after a purified protein derivative test was placed on his forearm. The test was placed in preparation for transfer from the acute care setting, where he was treated for diverticulitis and type 2 diabetes, to a rehabilitation setting. The patient has no symptoms of weight loss, fevers, or cough. He reports a history of exposure to a relative with tuberculosis.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in screening this patient for tuberculosis infection?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Treatment with antitubercular agents, such as rifampin or isoniazid, is not appropriate until a diagnosis is established.

B) INCORRECT:

The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommend that interferon-gamma release assays be used in place of tuberculin skin testing. However, the assay is not required in this case, because the purified protein derivative skin test is positive.

C) INCORRECT:

Treatment with antitubercular agents, such as rifampin or isoniazid, is not appropriate until a diagnosis is established.

D) INCORRECT:

Two-step tuberculin skin testing would be performed in patients whose tuberculin reaction may have waned (e.g., someone with remote exposure to tuberculosis antigens). In this case, the individual already has a positive purified protein derivative skin test.

E) CORRECT:

The finding of a 15-mm area of induration after placement of a purified protein derivative skin test is consistent with a diagnosis of either latent or active tuberculosis. A chest radiograph can determine whether an individual has evidence of active tuberculosis, even in the absence of symptoms.

The presence of type 2 diabetes increases the risk for reactivation and is an additional indicator that treatment is likely to be ultimately appropriate.

Key learning point: The next step in evaluating a patient with a positive purified protein derivative skin test is to obtain a chest radiograph to determine whether the individual has active pulmonary tuberculosis.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman who recently returned from a 2-month trip to India to visit family is found to have an 8-mm area of induration at the site of an intradermally placed purified protein derivative test. While in India, she visited a relative who was recently diagnosed with tuberculosis and was in the process of starting treatment.
The patient’s weight is stable, and she has no night sweats, cough, or hemoptysis. She received the bacille Calmette-Guérin vaccine as an infant. She is HIV-negative and has never been treated for tuberculosis.
Which one of the following next steps is best for this patient?

choices.text: Repeat purified protein derivative testing in 3 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If the chest radiograph is negative, an interferon-gamma release assay may help to determine whether the patient’s reaction was a false-positive, which occasionally occurs in patients with a history of bacille Calmette-Guérin immunization, or whether it represents latent TB, which would be treated per current guidelines.

B) CORRECT:

The interpretation of a purified protein derivative (PPD) test depends on the size of the area of induration and on the person’s risks for being infected with tuberculosis (TB) and for TB progression if infection occurs. A PPD reaction between 5 and 10 mm, as in this case, should be considered positive only in certain circumstances: HIV infection, recent exposure to a patient with active TB, fibrotic changes on chest radiography consistent with prior TB, use of immunosuppressive therapy for >30 days, and organ transplantation.

This patient was recently exposed to someone with active TB and should therefore be further evaluated. Chest radiography is indicated to determine whether this patient has findings consistent with active TB. If the chest radiograph suggests active disease, four-drug therapy for active TB (which includes rifampin) would be indicated. If the chest radiograph is negative, an interferon-gamma release assay may help to determine whether the patient’s reaction was a false-positive, which occasionally occurs in patients with a history of bacille Calmette-Guérin immunization, or whether it represents latent TB, which would be treated per current guidelines.

Key learning point: For a patient who was recently exposed to someone with active tuberculosis and is found to have a 5- to 10-mm area of induration after a purified protein derivative test, the best next step in care is chest radiography to assess for signs of active tuberculosis.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient was recently exposed to someone with active TB and should therefore be further evaluated. A PPD reaction between 5 and 10 mm, as in this case, should be considered positive in the context of recent exposure to a patient with active TB.

D) INCORRECT:

A repeat PPD test is indicated in certain circumstances of suspected anergy but has no role in a patient such as this, who has an 8-mm area of induration and known TB exposure.

E) INCORRECT:

If the chest radiograph suggests active disease, four-drug therapy for active TB (which includes rifampin) would be indicated. However, initiating rifampin therapy without further evaluation is not appropriate without first determining whether the patient has active TB or latent TB.

questions.text:

B) INCORRECT:

C) INCORRECT:

A repeat PPD test is indicated in certain circumstances of suspected anergy but has no role in a patient such as this, who has an 8-mm area of induration and known TB exposure.

This patient was recently exposed to someone with active TB and should therefore be further evaluated. If the chest radiograph is negative, an interferon-gamma release assay may help to determine whether the patient’s reaction was a false-positive, which occasionally occurs in patients with a history of bacille Calmette-Guérin immunization.

This patient was recently exposed to someone with active TB and should therefore be further evaluated. Chest radiography is indicated to determine whether this patient has findings consistent with active TB. If the chest radiograph suggests active disease, four-drug therapy for active TB (which includes rifampin) would be indicated.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old boy presents for evaluation of fever and cough that have been present since he moved from China 6 weeks ago to begin living with his adoptive parents in the United States. He has daily fevers that peak at 39°C, a frequent productive cough, and occasional post-tussive emesis. He has no rhinorrhea, congestion, or sore throat. His parents report that his appetite has decreased during the past 2 weeks. He was treated with a course of amoxicillin, but his symptoms have not improved.
His current temperature is 36.5°C, his respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 99% while he breathes ambient air. The rest of his physical examination is unrevealing.
A chest radiograph is significant for mediastinal fullness (figure).
What is the most appropriate next step in this child’s care?

choices.text: Obtain a nasopharyngeal sample for pertussis testing
Initiate treatment with albuterol and prednisolone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is appropriate for the treatment of community-acquired pneumonia in children older than age 5, in whom atypical pathogens such as Mycoplasma and Chlamydophila are possible. Although this patient's fever and cough could be indicative of a community-acquired pneumonia, the extended duration of the symptoms is more suggestive of another cause, such as TB, which should be excluded before proceeding with empiric treatment for pneumonia.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function testing can be helpful in the evaluation of a patient with reactive lung disease and asthma but is not likely to be informative for this child who has no audible wheezing and no suggestion of a reactive airway process.

C) INCORRECT:

Pertussis should be considered when evaluating a child with chronic cough, but this condition is not associated with fever as is described in this case, and the cough is not typically productive. Pertussis is characterized by a classic cough that may be associated with a whooping sound as the child inhales air over a closed glottis and tries to catch his breath. The cough can be associated with post-tussive emesis.

D) CORRECT:

Foreign-born children and children born in the United States to foreign-born parents have the highest rates of tuberculosis (TB) in the United States.

In a young child with cough, acute or subacute fever, and a plausible TB exposure history (especially immigration from a high-risk region), a tuberculin skin test is warranted. Young children can rarely produce sputum, so the collection of early morning gastric aspirates for acid-fast bacterial culture is recommended to confirm the diagnosis of pulmonary TB.

Although an interferon-gamma release assay has greater sensitivity and specificity than tuberculin skin testing, tuberculin skin testing currently remains the diagnostic test of choice in children younger than 2 years of age.

Key learning point: An 18-month-old child who has immigrated from China and presents with prolonged fever and a productive cough should be evaluated for tuberculosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Inhaled albuterol and oral glucocorticoids are appropriate treatments for reactive airway disease, but the presence of fever and cough is not consistent with this diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl lives with her mother in a homeless shelter where a neighbor was recently diagnosed with tuberculosis. A purified protein derivative test, placed on the child's arm, has 0 mm of induration. The child is well and has no symptoms of infection. She has normal vital signs and a normal pulmonary examination. A chest radiograph is normal.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Obtain three early-morning gastric aspirates for tuberculosis testing
Perform a boosted purified protein derivative test
Obtain an induced sputum sample for further evaluation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Young children swallow rather than expectorate their sputum, so three early-morning gastric aspirates have traditionally been used to isolate TB in children with pulmonary disease; however, the yield from this technique is only about 30% in children with probable active TB.

B) INCORRECT:

Either a PPD or IGRA could be used for follow-up testing after 12 weeks in this child. IGRAs and tuberculin skin tests appear to have similar sensitivity, but IGRAs are more specific than PPDs in all settings. Importantly, IGRAs have not been validated in young children and are recommended for use in the diagnosis of TB disease in children 2 years of age or older.

C) INCORRECT:

A boosted PPD test can be used in a child with suspected anergy if suspicion for TB is high, but it is not recommended for routine use in children.

D) CORRECT:

Infants and children who are exposed to tuberculosis (TB) have a particularly high risk of progression to disease and disseminated TB. Thus, in a child younger than 5 years of age, prophylactic treatment is indicated to prevent TB disease and should be started as soon as the exposure is recognized and active TB disease is ruled out. Prophylactic treatment consists of isoniazid administered for 12 weeks. At the end of the 12 weeks, repeat TB testing should be done with either a purified protein derivative skin test (PPD) or an interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA). If this repeat test is positive, the child should be evaluated for active disease — including a complete physical examination to detect possible signs of extrapulmonary TB and chest radiography to assess for active pulmonary disease. If follow-up TB testing remains negative, the isoniazid can be discontinued. If a PPD shows induration >5 mm or if an IGRA is positive and the child has no evidence of pulmonary or extrapulmonary infection, the isoniazid should be continued for an additional 6 months to complete 9 months of therapy for TB infection.

Key learning point: For a child younger than 5 years of age who has been exposed to someone with active tuberculosis and who is found to have a 0-mm area of induration in response to a purified protein derivative skin test, the most appropriate next step after obtaining a normal chest radiograph is initiation of 12 weeks of isoniazid prophylactic therapy followed by repeat tuberculosis testing.

E) INCORRECT:

The yield of induced sputum samples is notoriously low in children, because children tend to have lower concentrations of bacilli in their sputum and to produce less sputum than adults.

questions.text:
A young woman, 18 years of age, presents with 2 months of dry cough, increasing dyspnea, drenching night sweats, difficulty lying supine, and 4.5 kg of unintentional weight loss. She has no hemoptysis. She emigrated from Mexico to the United States 2 years ago and currently attends a local college where her screening tuberculin skin test was negative at admission. She recently returned from a trip to Mexico.
Chest radiograph demonstrates a large right pleural effusion and hilar lymphadenopathy.
Thoracentesis reveals straw-colored fluid, with 5000 white cells per mm3 (90% lymphocytes). The pleural fluid has a pH of 7.2, a protein level of 3.3 g/dL, and a glucose level of 55 mg/dL. A repeat tuberculin skin test is negative, and an HIV test is negative.
Which one of the following is most likely to identify the cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Obtain a pleural fluid interferon-gamma release assay
Order CT scan of the chest
Obtain a sputum culture for Mycobacterium tuberculosis
Arrange for pleural biopsy with mycobacterial culture
Stain the pleural fluid for acid-fast bacillus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although studies on pleural fluid, such as measurement of the adenosine deaminase level or an interferon-gamma release assay, may be helpful, different studies report varying sensitivities and specificities for these tests; the definitive test for pleural TB remains the pleural biopsy. Typical pleural fluid findings include pH <7.4, low glucose and a lymphocytic exudate.

B) INCORRECT:

Chest CT can be helpful if other features of TB are present, but this scenario is more common in older individuals with chronic TB and effusions.

C) INCORRECT:

Although sputum acid-fast bacilli staining and culture may reveal the diagnosis, in this case, the patient is not producing sputum, and a pleural biopsy has a higher yield.

D) CORRECT:

Pleural tuberculosis (TB) with an effusion may develop within weeks to months of initial infection (primary TB pleuritis) or in the setting of reactivation TB. Primary TB pleuritis is most often seen in children, whereas reactivation TB pleuritis is more common in adults. The pleural effusions are usually small to moderate in size but can be massive. They are typically unilateral but may be bilateral. The best diagnostic approach is to obtain a pleural biopsy. This biopsy specimen often shows granulomas; mycobacterial culture of a needle biopsy specimen may be positive even when granulomas are not seen on histologic examination.

The tuberculin skin test may initially be negative in the setting of TB pleuritis.

Key learning point: The best test to diagnose pleural tuberculosis is pleural biopsy with mycobacterial culture.

E) INCORRECT:

In primary TB pleuritis, acid-fast stains of the pleural fluid sediment are rarely positive, but in reactivation TB, they can be positive 50% of the time. Mycobacterial culture of the pleural fluid is positive 25% to 30% of the time when the pleurisy is in the setting of primary TB and 60% of the time when the pleurisy is due to reactivation.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy arrives at the emergency department reporting a 3-week history of productive cough, fatigue, night sweats, and intermittent fevers. He has no prior medical problems.
